contributor.username: Me, Myself, and I are Here

revision.text:
A '''patient diary''' is a tool used during a clinical trial or a disease treatment to assess the patient's condition (e.g. symptom severity, quality of life) or to measure treatment compliance. An '''electronic patient diary''' registers the data in a storage device and allows for automatically monitoring the time the entry was made.
Frequent recording of symptoms using a diary helps to reduce recall bias. Electronic diaries ensure entries are made as scheduled, and not, for example, in a batch immediately before the clinic visit.
Patient diaries are also way to find out if a patient takes the medication according to the treatment schedule, which is an important problem during clinical trials and the treatment of degenerative diseases with relatively few symptoms.
==See also== * [[Case report form]] * [[Electronic patient-reported outcome|Electronic patient reported outcomes (ePRO)]] * [[Patient-reported outcome]]
==References== * Stone AA, Broderick JE, Shiffman SS, Schwartz JE. Understanding recall of weekly pain from a momentary assessment perspective: absolute agreement, between- and within-person consistency, and judged change in weekly pain, Pain, 2004;107 (1-2): 61-69 * Tiplady B, Crompton GK, Brackenridge D. Electronic diaries for asthma, British Medical Journal, 1995; 310: 1469 * van Berge Henegouwen MT, van Driel HF, Kasteleijn-Nolst Trenite DG., A patient diary as a tool to improve medicine compliance, Pharm World Sci. 1999 Feb;21(1):21-4. * van Gerven JM, Schoemaker RC, Jacobs LD, Reints A, Ouwersloot-van der Meij MJ, Hoedemaker HG, Cohen AF., Self-medication of a single headache episode with ketoprofen, ibuprofen or placebo, home-monitored with an electronic patient diary, Br J Clin Pharmacol. 1996 Oct;42(4):475-81.
[[Category:Clinical research]] [[Category:Clinical data management]] [[Category:Quality of life]] [[Category:Patient]]

{{For|other people with the same name|Philip Key (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox person | name = Philip Barton Key II | occupation = [[Lawyer]] | image = HarpersMagazinePhilipBartonKey.jpg | image_size = | caption = ''[[Harper's Weekly]]'' engraving of Philip Barton Key from a photograph by [[Mathew Brady]] | birth_date = {{birth date|1818|4|5}} | birth_place = [[Georgetown, Washington, D.C.|Georgetown]], [[Washington, D.C.|D.C.]], United States | nationality = [[Americans|American]] | spouse = Ellen Swan | death_date = {{death date and age|1859|2|27|1818|4|5}} | death_place = [[Washington, D.C.]], United States | resting_place = [[Westminster Hall and Burying Ground]] | ethnicity = | parents = [[Francis Scott Key]]
Mary Tayloe Lloyd | children = James Key, Alice Key | relatives = | religion = }} '''Philip Barton Key''' (April 5, 1818 – February 27, 1859)Richardson, Hester Dorsey. ''Side-Lights on Maryland History: With Sketches of Early Maryland Families.'' Baltimore, Md.: Williams and Wilkins company, 1913. was an [[United States|American]] lawyer who served as [[United States Attorney for the District of Columbia|U.S. Attorney]] for the [[Washington, D.C.|District of Columbia]]. He is most famous for his public affair with [[Teresa Bagioli Sickles]], and his eventual murder at the hands of her husband, [[United States House of Representatives|Congressman]] [[Daniel Sickles]] of [[New York (state)|New York]]. Sickles defended himself by adopting a defense of [[Insanity defense#Temporary insanity|temporary insanity]], the first time the defense had been used in the United States.[[Gary W. Gallagher|Gallagher, Gary W.]] ''Three Days at Gettysburg: Essays on Confederate and Union Leadership.'' Kent, Ohio: Kent State University Press, 1999. {{ISBN|0-87338-629-9}}Spiegel, Allen D. ''Murder and Madness: Military Matters and Managed Medicine: Memorable Milestones and Moments.'' Charleston, S.C.: Heritage Books, 2007. {{ISBN|0-7884-4079-9}}; Wylie, Paul R. ''The Irish General: Thomas Francis Meagher.'' Stillwater, Okla.: University of Oklahoma Press, 2007. {{ISBN|0-8061-3847-5}} == Biography == [[File:HarpersMagazineMrs.Sickles.jpg|thumb|right|150px|''[[Harper's Weekly]]'' engraving of Mrs. Sickles from a photograph of [[Mathew Brady]]]] Born in [[Georgetown, Washington, D.C.|Georgetown]], [[Washington, D.C.|D.C.]], Key was the son of [[Francis Scott Key]]Walther, Eric H. ''The Shattering of the Union: America in the 1850s.'' New York: Rowman & Littlefield, 2004. {{ISBN|0-8420-2799-8}} and the great-nephew of [[Philip Barton Key (U.S. politician)|Philip Barton Key]]. He was also a nephew of Chief Justice [[Roger B. Taney]].Flower, Frank Abial. ''Edwin McMasters Stanton: The Autocrat of Rebellion, Emancipation, and Reconstruction.'' New York: W.W. Wilson, 1905. He married Ellen Swan, the daughter of a [[Baltimore]] attorney, on November 18, 1845. Allegedly the handsomest man in WashingtonTaylor, John M. ''William Henry Seward: Lincoln's Right Hand.'' New York: Brassey's, 1996. {{ISBN|1-57488-119-1}} and by 1859 a widower with four children, Key was known to be flirtatious with many women.Goode, James M. ''Capital Losses: A Cultural History of Washington's Destroyed Buildings.'' Washington, D.C.: Smithsonian Institution Press, 1981. {{ISBN|0-87474-479-2}}Before he married Ellen Swan, Key had been engaged to Virginia Timberlake, a daughter of [[Margaret O'Neill Eaton|Peggy Eaton]], the center of the [[Petticoat affair]] that bedeviled the cabinet of President [[Andrew Jackson]]. One of Key's great-granddaughters was the 1960s style icon [[Pauline de Rothschild]]. [[File:Coat of Arms of Francis Scott Key.svg|150px|thumb|left|Coat of Arms of Philip Barton Key II]] Some time in the spring of 1858, Teresa Sickles began an affair with Key. Dan Sickles, though a serial adulterer himself, had accused his much-younger wife of adultery several times during their five-year marriage, but she had repeatedly denied it to his satisfaction. But then Sickles received a [[poison pen letter]]from [http://www.assumption.edu/dept/history/Hi113net/sickles/default1.html assumption.edu] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060914160639/http://www.assumption.edu/dept/history/Hi113net/sickles/default1.html |date=2006-09-14 }} "The stories told how Sickles had received an anonymous letter on Thursday, February 24th, informing him of his wife's relationship with Key." informing him of his wife's affair with Key.The anonymous letter was reproduced in Harper's: [http://www.assumption.edu/acad/ii/Academic/history/Hi113net/sickles/anonletter.html Letter image] He confronted his wife, who confessed to the affair. Sickles then made his wife write out her confession on paper.Hartog, Hendrik. ''Man and Wife in America: A History.'' Reprint ed. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press, 2002. {{ISBN|0-674-00811-1}} [[File:Sickles homicide.jpg|thumb|right|''[[Harper's Weekly]]'' engraving of [[Daniel Sickles]] shooting Key]] Sickles saw Key sitting on a bench outside the Sickles home on February 27, 1859, signalling to Teresa, and confronted him.Tagg, Larry. ''The Generals of Gettysburg.'' Campbell, Calif.: Savas Publishing, 1998. {{ISBN|1-882810-30-9}}. p. 62. Sickles rushed outside into [[President's Park|Lafayette Square]], cried "Key, you scoundrel, you have dishonored my home; you must die",Flower, ''Edwin McMasters Stanton: The Autocrat of Rebellion, Emancipation, and Reconstruction,'' 1905, p. 73. and with a pistol repeatedly shot the unarmed Key. ==Death== Key was taken into the nearby [[Benjamin Ogle Tayloe House]], where he died some time later.Smith, Hal H. "Historic Washington Homes.'' ''Records of the Columbia Historical Society, Washington.'' 1908. Sickles was acquitted on the basis of [[Insanity defense#Temporary insanity|temporary insanity]], a [[crime of passion]], in one of the most controversial trials of the 19th century.{{Cite book | last = Twain | first = Mark | authorlink = Mark Twain | title = The Autobiography of Mark Twain, Volume One | publisher = University of California Press | year = 2010 | location = Berkeley, CA | pages = 566 | isbn = 978-0-520-26719-0}} It was the first successful use of the defense in the United States."Crime History", ''The Washington Examiner, Feb. 27, 2012, p. 8. One of Sickles' attorneys, [[Edwin Stanton]], later became the [[Secretary of War]]. Newspapers declared Sickles a hero for "saving" women from Key. Years later, while attending the theater in New York City, Sickles became aware of the presence of Key's son James Key in the audience; both men watched each other throughout the performance. Nothing happened.Brandt, Nat. ''The Congressman Who Got Away With Murder.'' Syracuse, N.Y.: University of Syracuse Press, 1991. {{ISBN|0-8156-0251-0}}. p. 213. Key is buried in his son-in-law's family plot in [[Westminster Hall and Burying Ground]] in [[Baltimore, Maryland|Baltimore]].{{cite web|title=Philip Barton Key II, Findagrave|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/9458197|accessdate=30 July 2015}} His first cousin once removed, also named [[Philip Barton Key (Louisiana)|Philip Barton Key, Jr.]], left Annapolis in 1835 to become a planter and state legislator in [[Louisiana]]. == Sources == {{reflist}} == External links == * {{Find a Grave|9458197}} * [http://politicalgraveyard.com/bio/kerrey-keydel.html ''The Political Graveyard''] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Key, Philip Barton}} [[Category:1818 births]] [[Category:1859 deaths]] [[Category:People from Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:American murder victims]] [[Category:Burials at Westminster Hall and Burying Ground]] [[Category:American prosecutors]] [[Category:Murdered lawyers]] [[Category:People murdered in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Deaths by firearm in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:United States Attorneys for the District of Columbia]] [[Category:Key family of Maryland]]

{{Redirect|Kuntilanak|the 2006 film|Kuntilanak (film)}} {{Other uses|Pontianak (disambiguation)}}
The '''pontianak''' (Dutch-Indonesian spelling: ''boentianak'', [[Jawi alphabet|Jawi]]: ڤونتيانق) is a female vampiric ghost in [[Malay folklore|Malay mythology]]. It is also known as a '''matianak''' or '''kuntilanak''', sometimes shortened to '''kunti'''. Pontianak is called '''[[Churel]]''', or '''Churayl''', in Bangladesh, India, and Pakistan. The pontianak are said to be the spirits of women who died while pregnant. This is despite the fact that the earliest recordings of pontianaks in Malay lore describe the ghost as originating from a [[stillborn]] child.<ref name="magic">{{Cite book|url=https://www.mirrorservice.org/sites/gutenberg.org/4/7/8/7/47873/47873-h/47873-h.htm|title=Malay Magic|last=Skeat|first=William Walter|publisher=MacMillan and Co|year=1900|isbn=|location=New York|pages=}}</ref><ref name="pagan">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rUATAAAAYAAJ|title=Pagan Races of the Malay Peninsula|last=Skeat|first=Walter William|last2=Blagden|first2=Charles Otto|date=1906-01-01|publisher=Macmillan and Company, limited|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yhZzAAAAMAAJ|title=Woman's Mysteries of a Primitive People: The Ibibios of Southern Nigeria|last=Talbot|first=D. Amaury|date=1915-01-01|publisher=Cassell and Company|pages=216–217|language=en}}</ref> This is often confused with a related creature, the [[lang suir]], which is the ghost of a woman who died while giving birth.
==Etymology== The word ''pontianak'' is reportedly a corruption of the [[Malay language|Malay]] ''perempuan mati beranak'', or “[[Maternal death|woman who died in childbirth]]”.<ref>Lee R. ''The Almost Complete Collection of True Singapore Ghost Stories.'' 2nd ed. Singapore: Flame of the Forest, 1989.</ref> Another theory is that the word is a combination of ''puan'' (woman) + ''mati'' (die) + ''anak'' (child). The term ''matianak'' means "death of a child". The city of [[Pontianak, Indonesia|Pontianak]] in Indonesia is named after this wicked creature, which was a ghosts' nest until Syarif Abdurrahman Alkadrie and his Army fought and extruded ghosts who attacked his group by shooting cannon balls.<ref>[http://www.bernama.com/bernama/v5/bm/newsfeatures.php?id=361412 Amrizan Madian; ''Matahari Tegak Dua Kali Setahun di Kota Khatulistiwa''; Situs Berita Nasional Malaysia] (''in Indonesian'')</ref>
==Appearance== Pontianaks are usually depicted as pale-skinned women with long black hair, red eyes, and white dress smeared in blood, but they are said to be able to take on a beautiful humanly appearance since they prey on men and helpless people. They can also be beasts due to their bloodthirsty and carnivorous nature.
In folklore, a pontianak usually arises at full moon and announces her presence through high-pitched baby cries. If the cry is soft, it means that the pontianak is near, and if it is loud, then she must be far. Some believe that if ones hears a dog howling at night, that means the pontianak is far, but if a dog is whining, that means the pontianak is nearby. Her presence can sometimes be detected by a nice floral fragrance identifiable as that of the [[plumeria]], followed by an awful stench (resembling that of a decaying body) afterwards. The Indian version, the Churail, can be identified by her feet turning backwards just before her transformation into her vampiric form.
A pontianak kills her victims by digging into their stomach with her sharp fingernails and devouring their body organs. In some cases where the pontianak desires revenge against a male individual, the beast rips out the body organs with her hands. It is said that if one has his or eyes open when a pontianak is near, she will suck them out of the victim's head. Pontianak locates her preys/victims by sniffing out the hanging laundry outside. For this reason, some Malaysians refuse to leave any piece of clothing outside of their house overnight.
The pontianak is associated with [[banana]] trees, and her spirit is said to reside in them during the day.
To fend off a pontianak, a nail should be plunged into the hole on the nape of her neck. This is said to make her turn into a beautiful woman and a good wife until the nail is removed. In the case of the kuntilanak, the nail is plunged into the apex of her head.
The Indonesian kuntilanak is similar to the pontianak, but commonly takes the form of a bird and sucks the blood of virgins and young women. The bird, which makes a "ke-ke-ke" sound as it flies, may be sent through some black magic to make a woman fell sick, the characteristic symptom is vaginal bleeding. In her female form, when a man approaches her, she suddenly turns and reveals that her back is hollow, but this apparition is more specifically referred to [[sundel bolong]].
==Sightings== There are numerous sightings of the Pontianak/Lang suir all over South East Asia, particularly in Malaysia and Indonesia. In August 2010 there was a video caught by a group of Malaysian Policeman [[PDRM]] in the town of Bentong, Pahang, Malaysia. The 2-minute-long video does not show the apparition of the Pontianak at all in her full form.<ref>Chandran83. [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Vl5DYZ0UoGQ "PONTIANAK LEPAR HILIR 7,PAHANG,MALAYSIA"] ''[[YouTube]]'', Pahang, 15 August 2010. Retrieved on 5 February 2013.</ref>
==In popular culture== * Indonesian films, see also [[:id:Kategori:Film kuntilanak]] ** ''Kuntilanak'' (1962) starring [[Ateng]] ** ''Kuntilanak'' (1974) ** ''Lawang Sewu'' (2007) ** ''Casablanca Tunnel (Red Kuntilanak)'' (2007) ** ''Kuntilanak's Nest'' (2008) ** ''[[Kuntilanak (film)|Kuntilanak]]'' (2006), ''Kuntilanak 2'' (2007), ''Kuntilanak 3'' (2008) ** ''Kuntilanak's Morgue'' (2009) ** ''Kuntilanak Beranak'' (2009) ** ''The Nail of Kuntilanak'' (2009) ** ''Santet Kuntilanak'' (2012) *Indonesian Video Game ** ''[[DreadOut]]'' (2014) * Malaysian films ** ''The Pontianak Child'' (1958) ** ''Pontianak Musang Cave'' (1964) ** ''The Return of Kuntilanak'' (1963) ** ''[[Pontianak Harum Sundal Malam]]'' (2004) ** ''Pontianak Harum Sundal Malam 2'' (2005) ** ''[[The Scream of Pontianak]]'' (2005) ** ''[[Help Me, I'm a Pontianak]]'' (2011) ** ''[[Pontianak vs Oil Person]]'' (2012) ** ''[[The Nail of Kuntilanak]]'' (2013) * Malaysian fiction ** ''The House of Aunts'' (2011) by [[Zen Cho]]<ref>{{cite news | title = The House of Aunts | date = 2011-12-01 | url = http://giganotosaurus.org/2011/12/01/the-house-of-aunts/ | accessdate = 2015-04-13}}</ref> *American fiction **''[[Supernatural (U.S. TV series)|Supernatural]]: Cold Fire''
==Related folklore== {{Main|Tiyanak}} In [[Philippines|Philippine]] folklore, the vampiric [[tiyanak]] shares many similarities in terms of origin with the pontianak. However, the tiyanak is the ghost of the child rather than the mother.
==See also== {{Portal|Folklore}} *[[Malay folklore]] *[[Sundel Bolong]] *[[Lang Suir]] *[[White Lady (ghost)]] *[[Tai Thong Klom]] *[[Keres (mythology)|Keres]] (Κῆρες), spirits of violent or cruel death in [[Greek mythology]] *[[Hun and po#History|Hun and po]] *[[Onryō]] *[[Mavka]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.dukunindonesia.com/mysticism/myths-legends/kuntilanak-pontianak/ Kuntilanak ('Pontianak'): 'The Ghost of a Woman Who Died While Pregnant' | Dukun Indonesia] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100219044550/http://spi.com.sg/spi/spi_files/pontianak/ Article by Singapore Paranormal Investigators about pontianaks] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051022135117/http://courses.nus.edu.sg/course/elltrw/History/Pontianaks%20%26%20Verisimilitude.doc Pontianaks And The Issue Of Verisimilitude In Singaporean Cinema(requires a login and password)]—an essay by Dr Timothy White of the National University of Singapore, about the important role played by 1950s and 1960s horror films in the evolution of pontianak mythology (Microsoft Word document).
{{Mythology of Indonesia}} {{Mythology of Malaysia}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Pontianak (Folklore)}} [[Category:Indonesian legendary creatures]] [[Category:Malay ghost myth]] [[Category:Malay folklore]] [[Category:Vampires]] [[Category:Corporeal undead]] [[Category:Indonesian folklore]] [[Category:Jinn]] [[Category:Female legendary creatures]] [[Category:Ghosts]]

{{Infobox medical condition | Name = Puerperal disorder | Image = | Caption = | DiseasesDB = | ICD10 = {{ICD10|O|85||o|85}}-{{ICD10|O|92||o|85}} | ICD9 = {{ICD9|670}}-{{ICD9|676}} | ICDO = | OMIM = | MedlinePlus = | eMedicineSubj = | eMedicineTopic = | MeshID = D011644 }} A '''puerperal disorder''' or '''postpartum disorder''' is a [[Disease|disorder]] which presents primarily during the puerperium, or [[postpartum period]]. The postpartum period can be divided into three distinct stages; the initial or acute phase, 6–12 hours after childbirth; subacute postpartum period, which lasts 2–6 weeks, and the delayed postpartum period, which can last up to 6 months.<ref name="Romano_2010">{{cite journal | vauthors = Romano M, Cacciatore A, Giordano R, La Rosa B | title = Postpartum period: three distinct but continuous phases | journal = Journal of Prenatal Medicine | volume = 4 | issue = 2 | pages = 22–5 | date = April 2010 | pmid = 22439056 | pmc = 3279173 }}</ref> In the subacute postpartum period, 87% to 94% of women report at least one health problem.<ref name="Glazener_1995">{{cite journal | vauthors = Glazener CM, Abdalla M, Stroud P, Naji S, Templeton A, Russell IT | title = Postnatal maternal morbidity: extent, causes, prevention and treatment | journal = British Journal of Obstetrics and Gynaecology | volume = 102 | issue = 4 | pages = 282–7 | date = April 1995 | pmid = 7612509 | doi = 10.1111/j.1471-0528.1995.tb09132.x }}</ref><ref name="Thompson_2002">{{cite journal | vauthors = Thompson JF, Roberts CL, Currie M, Ellwood DA | title = Prevalence and persistence of health problems after childbirth: associations with parity and method of birth | journal = Birth (Berkeley, Calif.) | volume = 29 | issue = 2 | pages = 83–94 | date = June 2002 | pmid = 12051189 | doi = 10.1046/j.1523-536X.2002.00167.x }}</ref> Long term health problems (persisting after the delayed postpartum period) are reported by 31% of women.<ref name="Borders_2006">{{cite journal | vauthors = Borders N | title = After the afterbirth: a critical review of postpartum health relative to method of delivery | journal = Journal of Midwifery & Women's Health | volume = 51 | issue = 4 | pages = 242–248 | date = 2006 | pmid = 16814217 | doi = 10.1016/j.jmwh.2005.10.014 }}</ref>
The [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) describes the postpartum period as the most critical and yet the most neglected phase in the lives of mothers and babies; most maternal and/or newborn deaths occur during the postpartum period.<ref name="World Health Organization">{{cite web | url=http://www.who.int/maternal_child_adolescent/documents/postnatal-care-recommendations/en/ | title=WHO recommendations on postnatal care of the mother and newborn | publisher=WHO | access-date=22 December 2014 | author=WHO}}</ref>
== Physical disorders == === Diastasis recti === [[Diastasis recti]] is a gap between the two sides of the [[rectus abdominis muscle]] that can occur in the antenatal and postnatal periods.<ref name="Review">{{cite journal|last1=Benjamin|first1=D.R.|last2=Van de Water|first2=A.T.M|last3=Peiris|first3=C.L.|date=March 2014|title=Effects of exercise on diastasis of the rectus abdominis muscle in the antenatal and postnatal periods: a systematic review|journal=Physiotherapy|volume=100|issue=1|pages=1–8|doi=10.1016/j.physio.2013.08.005|pmid=24268942}}</ref> This condition has no associated morbidity or mortality.<ref name="Norton, Jeffrey A. 2003 350">{{cite book|title=Essential practice of surgery: basic science and clinical evidence|author=Norton, Jeffrey A.|publisher=Springer|year=2003|isbn=0-387-95510-0|location=Berlin|pages=350}}</ref> Treatment is physiotherapy.
=== Haemorrhage === {{Main|Postpartum bleeding}}Primary postpartum haemorrhage is blood loss following childbirth of more than 500ml (minor) or 1000ml (major) <ref>{{cite journal|year=2016|title=Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/1471-0528.14178/epdf|deadurl=no|volume=124|pages=e106–e149|doi=10.1111/1471-0528.14178|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170214002449/http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/1471-0528.14178/epdf|archivedate=2017-02-14|website=RCOG}} Secondary postpartum haemorrhage</ref> Secondary postpartum haemorrhage is abnormal or excessive bleeding after 24 hours and before 12 weeks postnatally.<ref>{{cite journal|year=2016|title=Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/1471-0528.14178/epdf|deadurl=no|volume=124|pages=e106–e149|doi=10.1111/1471-0528.14178|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170214002449/http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/1471-0528.14178/epdf|archivedate=2017-02-14|website=RCOG}}</ref>
=== Incontinence === [[Urinary incontinence]] and [[fecal incontinence]] have been linked to all methods of childbirth, with the incidence of urinary incontinence at 6 months postpartum being 3-7% and fecal incontinence 1-3%.<ref name="Borders 2006" />
===Infection=== [[Postpartum infections]], also known as childbed fever and puerperal fever, are any bacterial [[infection]]s of the [[female reproductive tract]] following [[childbirth]] or [[miscarriage]]. Signs and symptoms usually include a [[fever]] greater than 38.0 °C (100.4 °F), chills, lower abdominal pain, and possibly bad-smelling [[vaginal discharge]]. It usually occurs after the first 24 hours and within the first ten days following delivery.
=== Mastitis === Puerperal [[mastitis]] is inflammation of the breast usually associated with [[breastfeeding]]. Symptoms typically include local pain and redness.<ref name="Ob2016">{{cite journal|last1=Berens|first1=PD|date=December 2015|title=Breast Pain: Engorgement, Nipple Pain, and Mastitis.|journal=Clinical obstetrics and gynecology|volume=58|issue=4|pages=902–14|doi=10.1097/GRF.0000000000000153|pmid=26512442}}</ref> There is often an associated [[fever]] and general soreness.<ref name="Ob2016" /> Onset is typically fairly rapid and usually occurs within the first few months of delivery.<ref name="Ob2016" /> Complications can include [[abscess]] formation.<ref name="AFP2008">{{cite journal|last1=Spencer|first1=JP|date=15 September 2008|title=Management of mastitis in breastfeeding women.|journal=American Family Physician|volume=78|issue=6|pages=727–31|pmid=18819238}}</ref>
===Obstetric fistula=== [[Obstetric fistula]] is a medical condition in which a [[Fistula|hole]] develops in the [[birth canal]] as a result of [[childbirth]], typically after a prolonged [[obstructed labour]]<ref name="WHO2014Fact">{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/features/factfiles/obstetric_fistula/en/|title=10 facts on obstetric fistula|date=May 2014|website=WHO|accessdate=12 December 2017}}</ref><ref name="UN2017">{{cite web|url=http://www.unfpa.org/obstetric-fistula|title=Obstetric fistula|date=8 May 2017|website=UNFPA - United Nations Population Fund|language=en|accessdate=12 December 2017}}</ref> and is preventable with timely access to [[Caesarean section|Cesarean section]]. The fistula can occur between the [[vagina]] and [[Rectovaginal fistula|rectum]], [[ureter]], or [[Vesicovaginal fistula|bladder]].<ref name="UN2017" /><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=XHcWNRVHWsEC&pg=PA370|title=Shaw's Textbook of Operative Gynaecology - E-Book|last1=Setchell|first1=Marcus E.|last2=Hudson|first2=C. N.|date=2013|publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences|isbn=8131234819|page=370|language=en}}</ref> It can result in [[Urinary incontinence|incontinence of urine]] or feces. <ref name="UN2017" />
=== Perineal tearing === [[Perineal tear]]ing is the spontaneous (unintended) tearing of the skin and other soft tissue structures which, in women, separate the vagina from the anus. Perineal tearing occurs in 85% of vaginal deliveries.<ref>McCandlish, R., Bowler, U., Asten, H., Berridge, G., Winter, C., Sames, L., ... & Elbourne, D. (1998). A randomised controlled trial of care of the perineum during second stage of normal labour. BJOG: an international journal of obstetrics & gynaecology, 105(12), 1262-1272.{{cite journal|author=McCandlish Rona, Bowler Ursula, Asten Hedwig, Berridge Georgina, Winter Cathy, Sames Lesley, Garcia Jo, Renfrew Mary, Elbourne Diana|year=1998|title=Archived copy|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1471-0528.1998.tb10004.x/full|deadurl=no|journal=BJOG: An International Journal of Obstetrics and Gynaecology|volume=105|pages=1262–1272|doi=10.1111/j.1471-0528.1998.tb10004.x|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150603020057/http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1471-0528.1998.tb10004.x/full|archivedate=2015-06-03|accessdate=2015-07-08}}</ref> At 6 months postpartum, 21% of women still report perineal pain<ref name="Borders 2006">Borders, N. (2006). After the afterbirth: a critical review of postpartum health relative to method of delivery. Journal of Midwifery & Women's health, 51(4), 242-248.{{cite web|url=http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/540896_2 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-07-08 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150511184953/http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/540896_2 |archivedate=2015-05-11 }} </ref> and 11-49% report sexual problems or painful intercourse.<ref name="Borders 2006" />
=== Peripartum cardiomyopathy === [[Peripartum cardiomyopathy]] is decrease in heart function which occurs in the last month of pregnancy, or up to 6 months post-pregnancy. It increases the risk of [[congestive heart failure]], heart [[arrhythmias]], [[thromboembolism]], and [[cardiac arrest]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pearson|first=G. D.|last2=Veille|first2=J. C.|last3=Rahimtoola|first3=S.|last4=Hsia|first4=J.|last5=Oakley|first5=C. M.|last6=Hosenpud|first6=J. D.|last7=Ansari|first7=A.|last8=Baughman|first8=K. L.|date=2000-03-01|title=Peripartum cardiomyopathy: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute and Office of Rare Diseases (National Institutes of Health) workshop recommendations and review|journal=JAMA|volume=283|issue=9|pages=1183–1188|issn=0098-7484|pmid=10703781|doi=10.1001/jama.283.9.1183}}</ref>
===Postpartum thyroiditis=== [[Postpartum thyroiditis]] is a phenomenon observed following [[pregnancy]]<ref name="pmid11588143">{{cite journal |vauthors=Muller AF, Drexhage HA, Berghout A |title=Postpartum thyroiditis and autoimmune thyroiditis in women of childbearing age: recent insights and consequences for antenatal and postnatal care |journal=Endocr. Rev. |volume=22 |issue=5 |pages=605–30 |date=October 2001 |pmid=11588143 |doi= 10.1210/er.22.5.605|url=http://edrv.endojournals.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=11588143}}</ref> and may involve [[hyperthyroidism]], [[hypothyroidism]] or the two sequentially. It affects about 5% of all women within a year after giving birth.
=== Pelvic organ prolapse === [[Pelvic organ prolapse]] occurs when the [[uterus]], [[bladder]] and/or [[rectum]] drop lower in the pelvis creating a bulge in the [[vagina]]. Approximately half of all women who have given birth experience some degree of pelvic organ prolapse, most frequently as they age and go through [[menopause]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hysterectomy-association.org.uk/information/why-do-i-need-a-hysterectomy/prolapse/|title=Pelvic organ prolapse|work=Hysterectomy Association|access-date=2018-04-03|language=en-GB}}</ref>
== Psychological disorders == {{Main|Psychiatric disorders of childbirth}}
=== Postpartum depression === [[Postpartum depression]] is a moderate to severe depressive episode starting anytime during pregnancy or within the four weeks following delivery. It occurs in 4-20% of pregnancies, depending on its definition.<ref name="Borders 2006" /> Without treatment, postpartum depression can last for months or years. In addition to affecting the mother’s health, it can interfere with her ability to connect with and care for her baby and may cause the baby to have problems with sleeping, eating, and behavior as he or she grows.<ref>{{cite web|title=Postpartum Depression Facts|url=https://www.nimh.nih.gov/health/publications/postpartum-depression-facts/index.shtml|website=National Institute of Mental Health|accessdate=May 5, 2018}}</ref> In 38% of the cases of postpartum depression, women are still depressed 3 years postpartum.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Vliegen N.|author2=Casalin S.|author3=Luyten P.|year=2014|title=The course of postpartum depression: a review of longitudinal studies|url=http://journals.lww.com/hrpjournal/Abstract/2014/01000/The_Course_of_Postpartum_Depression___A_Review_of.1.aspx|deadurl=no|journal=Harvard Review of Psychiatry|volume=22|issue=1|pages=1–22|doi=10.1097/hrp.0000000000000013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150709152407/http://journals.lww.com/hrpjournal/Abstract/2014/01000/The_Course_of_Postpartum_Depression___A_Review_of.1.aspx|archivedate=2015-07-09}}</ref> In 0.2% of pregnancies, postpartum depression leads to [[postpartum psychosis]].<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Sit D.|author2=Rothschild A. J.|author3=Wisner K. L.|year=2006|title=A review of postpartum psychosis|url=http://online.liebertpub.com/doi/abs/10.1089/jwh.2006.15.352|journal=Journal of women's health|volume=15|issue=4|pages=352–368|doi=10.1089/jwh.2006.15.352}}</ref>
=== Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) === {{Main|Childbirth-related posttraumatic stress disorder}}Research shows that symptoms of [[Posttraumatic stress disorder]] are common following childbirth, with prevalence of 24-30.1%<ref name=":0" /> at 6 weeks, dropping to 13.6% at 6 months.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Montmasson H.|author2=Bertrand P.|author3=Perrotin F.|author4=El-Hage W.|year=2012|title=[Predictors of postpartum post-traumatic stress disorder in primiparous mothers]|journal=Journal de gynecologie, obstetrique et biologie de la reproduction|volume=41|issue=6|pages=553–560|doi=10.1016/j.jgyn.2012.04.010|pmid=22622194}}</ref> PTSD is rarer; a review found that following normal childbirth (excluding stillbirth and some other complications) rates of PTSD ranged from 2.8-5.6% after 6 weeks, dropping to 1.5% at 6 months.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Olde|first=Eelco|last2=van der Hart|first2=Onno|last3=Kleber|first3=Rolf|last4=van Son|first4=Maarten|date=January 2006|title=Posttraumatic stress following childbirth: a review|journal=Clinical Psychology Review|volume=26|issue=1|pages=1–16|doi=10.1016/j.cpr.2005.07.002|issn=0272-7358|pmid=16176853}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Postpartum physiological changes]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Pathology of pregnancy, childbirth and the puerperium}}
[[Category:Childbirth]] [[Category:Pathology of pregnancy, childbirth and the puerperium]]

revision.comment: Replace "Irish elk" by "Giant deer". As the article on it says, it was neither an elk nor particularly Irish, so let's use the more correct name.
revision.text:
[[File:Ice_age_fauna_of_northern_Spain_-_Mauricio_Antón.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Ice_age_fauna_of_northern_Spain_-_Mauricio_Ant%C3%B3n.jpg|thumb|327x327px|Late [[Pleistocene]] landscape of northern [[Spain]], by [[Mauricio Antón]] (left to right: ''[[Horse|Equus ferus]]'', ''[[Woolly mammoth|Mammuthus primigenius]]'', ''[[Reindeer|Rangifer tarandus]], [[Panthera leo spelaea]], [[Woolly rhinoceros|Coelodonta antiquitatis]]'')]] The [[Quaternary]] period (from 2.588 ± 0.005 million years ago to the present) saw the [[extinction]]s of numerous predominantly [[megafauna]]l species, which resulted in a collapse in faunal density and diversity and the extinction of key ecological strata across the globe. The most prominent event in the [[Late Pleistocene]] is differentiated from previous Quaternary [[Turnover-pulse hypothesis|pulse extinctions]] by the widespread absence of [[ecological succession]] to replace these extinct species, and the [[regime shift]] of previously established faunal relationships and habitats as a consequence.
The earliest casualties were incurred at [[Eemian|130,000 BCE]] (the [[Eemian|start]] of the Late Pleistocene). However, the great majority of extinctions in [[Afro-Eurasia]] and the [[Americas]] occurred during the transition from the [[Pleistocene]] to the [[Holocene]] epoch (13,000 BCE to 8,000 BCE). This extinction wave did not stop at the end of the Pleistocene, continuing, especially on isolated islands, in [[Holocene extinction|human-caused extinctions]], although there is debate as to whether these should be considered separate events or part of the same event.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Sixth Extinction: An Unnatural History|last=Kolbert|first=Elizabeth|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|year=2014|isbn=9780805092998|title-link=The Sixth Extinction: An Unnatural History}}</ref>
Among the main causes hypothesized by [[paleontologists]] are overkill by [[Anatomically modern human|the widespread appearance of humans]] and natural [[climate change]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Koch|first=Paul L.|last2=Barnosky|first2=Anthony D.|date=2006-01-01|title=Late Quaternary Extinctions: State of the Debate|journal=Annual Review of Ecology, Evolution, and Systematics|volume=37|issue=1|pages=215–250|doi=10.1146/annurev.ecolsys.34.011802.132415}}</ref> A notable modern human presence first appeared during the [[Middle Pleistocene]] in Africa,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Stringer|first=Chris|last2=Galway-Witham|first2=Julia|title=Palaeoanthropology: On the origin of our species|journal=Nature|volume=546|issue=7657|pages=212–214|doi=10.1038/546212a|pmid=28593955|year=2017|bibcode=2017Natur.546..212S}}</ref> and started to establish continuous, permanent populations in [[Eurasia]] and [[Australasia]] from 120,000 BCE and 63,000 BCE respectively,<ref name=":02">{{Cite journal|last=Callaway|first=Ewen|title=Teeth from China reveal early human trek out of Africa|url=http://www.nature.com/news/teeth-from-china-reveal-early-human-trek-out-of-africa-1.18566|journal=Nature|doi=10.1038/nature.2015.18566|year=2015}}</ref><ref name=":22">{{Cite news|url=https://theconversation.com/buried-tools-and-pigments-tell-a-new-history-of-humans-in-australia-for-65-000-years-81021|title=Buried tools and pigments tell a new history of humans in Australia for 65,000 years|last=Marwick|first=Ben|work=The Conversation|access-date=2017-09-07}}</ref> and [[Prehistoric migration and settlement of the Americas from Asia|the Americas]] from 22,000 BCE.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Bourgeon|first=Lauriane|last2=Burke|first2=Ariane|last3=Higham|first3=Thomas|date=2017-01-06|title=Earliest Human Presence in North America Dated to the Last Glacial Maximum: New Radiocarbon Dates from Bluefish Caves, Canada|journal=PLOS ONE|volume=12|issue=1|pages=e0169486|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0169486|pmid=28060931|pmc=5218561|issn=1932-6203|bibcode=2017PLoSO..1269486B}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Curry|first=Andrew|date=2012-05-03|title=Ancient migration: Coming to America|url=https://www.nature.com/news/ancient-migration-coming-to-america-1.10562|journal=Nature|volume=485|issue=7396|pages=30–32|doi=10.1038/485030a|pmid=22552076|bibcode=2012Natur.485...30C}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2016/06/humans-didn-t-wait-melting-ice-settle-americas|title=Humans didn’t wait on melting ice to settle the Americas|date=2016-06-06|work=Science {{!}} AAAS|access-date=2017-09-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Callaway|first=Ewen|date=2017-09-07|title=Skeleton plundered from Mexican cave was one of the Americas' oldest|url=http://www.nature.com/news/skeleton-plundered-from-mexican-cave-was-one-of-the-americas-oldest-1.22521?WT.mc_id=SFB_NNEWS_1508_RHBox|journal=Nature|volume=549|issue=7670|pages=14–15|doi=10.1038/nature.2017.22521|pmid=28880302|bibcode=2017Natur.549...14C}}</ref>
A variant of the former possibility is the [[Quaternary extinction event#Second-order predation|second-order predation]] hypothesis, which focuses more on the indirect damage caused by overcompetition with nonhuman predators. Recent studies have tended to favor the human-overkill theory.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Sandom|first=Christopher |last2= Faurby|first2=Søren|last3= Sandel|first3=Brody|last4= Svenning|first4=Jens-Christian|date= 4 June 2014|title=Global late Quaternary megafauna extinctions linked to humans, not climate change |url=http://rspb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/281/1787/20133254 |journal=[[Proceedings of the Royal Society B]] |volume=281 |issue= 1787|page= 20133254|doi=10.1098/rspb.2013.3254|pmid=24898370 |pmc=4071532 |access-date=July 30, 2017 }}</ref><ref>Extinctions in Near Time. Pages 46–47. By R. D. E. MacPhee. Springer Press. 1999.</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Vignieri|first1=S.|date=25 July 2014|title=Vanishing fauna (Special issue)|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/site/special/vanishing/index.xhtml?_ga=1.172413478.429831163.1471029002|journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]]|volume=345|issue=6195|pages=392–412|doi=10.1126/science.345.6195.392|pmid=25061199|quote="Although some debate persists, most of the evidence suggests that humans were responsible for extinction of this Pleistocene fauna, and we continue to drive animal extinctions today through the destruction of wild lands, consumption of animals as a resource or a luxury, and persecution of species we see as threats or competitors."}}</ref>
==Pleistocene or Ice Age extinction event== {{See also|Timeline of extinctions in the Holocene}}The Late Pleistocene extinction event saw the extinction of many mammals weighing more than 40 kg. The proportional rate of megafauna extinctions is consecutively larger the greater the human migratory distance from Africa. * In [[Subsaharan Africa]], 8 of 50 (16%) [[Genus|genera]] of mammalian megafauna were driven to extinction. * In [[Asia]], 24 of 46 (52%) * In [[Europe]], 23 of 39 (59%) * In [[Australasia]], 19 of 27 (71%) * In [[North America]], 45 of 61 (74%) * In [[South America]], 58 of 71 (82%) The extinctions in the [[Americas]] entailed the elimination of all the larger (over 1000 kg) mammalian species of South American origin, including those that had migrated north in the [[Great American Interchange]]. Only in the continents of Australia, North America, and South America did the extinction occur at family taxonomic levels or higher.
The proportional rate of megafauna extinctions being incrementally bigger the larger the migratory distance from Africa might be related to non-African megafauna and ''[[Homo sapiens]]'' not having evolved as species alongside each other.
For their part, Australia, North America and South America, which respectively had the highest incremental extinction rates, had no known native species of [[Hominoidea]] (apes) at all, and specifically no species of [[Hominidae]] (greater apes) or [[Homo]]. The increased rate of extinction mirrors the sequential pattern of the migration of anatomically modern humans. The further away from Africa, the more recently the area has been inhabited by humans, and the less time the environments (including its megafauna) had had to become accustomed to humans and vice versa.
There is no evidence of megafaunal extinctions at the height of the [[Last Glacial Maximum]], indicating that increasing cold and glaciation were not factors.<ref name="cooper20152">{{cite journal|last1=Rabanus-Wallace|first1=M. Timothy|last2=Wooller|first2=Matthew J.|last3=Zazula|first3=Grant D.|last4=Shute|first4=Elen|last5=Jahren|first5=A. Hope|last6=Kosintsev|first6=Pavel|last7=Burns|first7=James A.|last8=Breen|first8=James|last9=Llamas|first9=Bastien|year=2017|title=Megafaunal isotopes reveal role of increased moisture on rangeland during late Pleistocene extinctions|journal=Nature Ecology & Evolution|volume=1|issue=5|page=0125|doi=10.1038/s41559-017-0125|pmid=28812683|last10=Cooper|first10=Alan}}</ref> There are three main hypotheses concerning the Pleistocene extinction: * The animals died off due to [[climate change]] associated with the advance and retreat of major [[ice caps]] or [[ice sheets]]. * The animals were exterminated by humans: the "prehistoric overkill hypothesis" (Martin, 1967).<ref name="Updating Martin 20082">{{cite journal|last1=Gillespie|first1=Richard|year=2008|title=Updating Martin's global extinction model|url=|journal=Quaternary Science Reviews|volume=27|issue=27–28|pages=2522–2529|bibcode=2008QSRv...27.2522G|doi=10.1016/j.quascirev.2008.09.007}}</ref> * The extinction of the [[woolly mammoth]] (by whatever cause, perhaps by humans) changed the extensive grasslands to birch forests, and subsequent forest fires then changed the climate.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Grayson|first1=Donald K.|last2=Meltzer|first2=David J.|date=2002|journal=Journal of World Prehistory|title=Clovis Hunting and Large Mammal Extinction: A Critical Review of the Evidence|volume=16|issue=4|pages=313–359|doi=10.1023/A:1022912030020}}</ref> We now know that immediately after the extinction of the mammoth, birch forests replaced the grasslands and that an era of significant fire began.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Doughty|first1=Christopher E.|last2=Wolf|first2=Adam|last3=Field|first3=Christopher B.|date=August 2010|title=Biophysical feedbacks between the Pleistocene megafauna extinction and climate: The first human-induced global warming?|journal=Geophysical Research Letters|volume=37|issue=15|pages=n/a|bibcode=2010GeoRL..3715703D|doi=10.1029/2010GL043985}}</ref> There are some inconsistencies between the current available data and the prehistoric overkill hypothesis. For instance, there are ambiguities around the timing of sudden extinctions of [[Australian megafauna]].<ref name="Updating Martin 20082" /> Biologists note that comparable extinctions have not occurred in [[Africa]] and [[South Asia|South]] or [[Southeast Asia]], where the fauna evolved with hominids. Post-glacial megafaunal extinctions in Africa have been spaced over a longer interval.
Evidence supporting the prehistoric overkill hypothesis includes the persistence of certain island megafauna for several millennia past the disappearance of their continental cousins. [[Megalocnus|Ground sloths]] survived on the [[Antilles]] long after North and South American ground sloths were extinct. The later disappearance of the island species correlates with the later colonization of these islands by humans. Similarly, woolly mammoths died out on remote [[Wrangel Island]] 1,000 years after their extinction on the mainland. [[Steller's sea cow]]s also persisted in seas off the isolated and uninhabited [[Commander Islands]] for thousands of years after they had vanished from the continental shores of the north Pacific.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Anderson|first=Paul K.|date=July 1995|title=Competition, Predation, and the Evolution and Extinction of Steller's Sea Cow, ''Hydrodamalis Gigas''|journal=Marine Mammal Science|volume=11|issue=3|pages=391–4|doi=10.1111/j.1748-7692.1995.tb00294.x}}</ref>
Alternative hypotheses to the theory of human responsibility include [[climate change]] associated with the [[last glacial period]] and the [[Younger Dryas event]], as well as [[Tollmann's hypothetical bolide]], which claim that the extinctions resulted from [[bolide]] impact(s). Such a scenario has been proposed as a contributing cause of the 1,300-year cold period known as the [[Younger Dryas]] stadial. {{citation needed|date=May 2012}} This impact extinction hypothesis is still in debate due to the exacting field techniques required to extract minuscule particles of extraterrestrial impact markers such as [[iridium]] at a high resolution from very thin strata in a repeatable fashion, as is necessary to conclusively distinguish the event peak from the local background level of the marker.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}} The debate seems to be exacerbated by infighting between the [[Uniformitarianism]] camp and the [[Catastrophism]] camp.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}} ===Africa and Asia=== {{See also|List of African animals extinct in the Holocene|List of Asian animals extinct in the Holocene}}The Old World tropics were relatively spared the Late Pleistocene extinctions. [[Sub-Saharan Africa]] and [[Asia|southern Asia]] are the only regions that have terrestrial mammals weighing over 1000 kg today. However, there are indications of a megafaunal extinction events throughout the Pleistocene, particularly in Africa two million years ago, which coincide with key stages of human evolution and climatic trends.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Werdelin|first=Lars|last2=Lewis|first2=Margaret E.|date=2013-03-06|title=Temporal Change in Functional Richness and Evenness in the Eastern African Plio-Pleistocene Carnivoran Guild|journal=PLOS ONE|volume=8|issue=3|pages=e57944|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0057944|pmid=23483948|pmc=3590191|issn=1932-6203|bibcode=2013PLoSO...857944W}}</ref><ref name="Tollefson">{{Cite journal|last=Tollefson|first=Jeff|title=Early humans linked to large-carnivore extinctions|url=http://www.nature.com/news/early-humans-linked-to-large-carnivore-extinctions-1.10508?nc=1370632369631|journal=Nature|doi=10.1038/nature.2012.10508|year=2012}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/observations/rise-of-humans-two-million-years-ago-doomed-large-carnivores/|title=Rise of Humans 2 Million Years Ago Doomed Large Carnivores|last=Wong|first=Kate|work=Scientific American Blog Network|access-date=2017-09-11}}</ref> The centre of human evolution and expansion, Africa and Asia were inhabited by advanced hominids by 2mya, with ''Homo habilis'' in Africa, and ''Homo erectus'' in both continents. By the advent and proliferation of ''Homo sapiens'' circa 298,000 BCE,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/2017/06/morocco-early-human-fossils-anthropology-science/|title=These Early Humans Lived 300,000 Years Ago—But Had Modern Faces|date=2017-06-07|access-date=2017-10-13}}</ref> dominant species included ''Homo heidelbergensis'' in Africa, and (their descendants) [[Denisovan]]s and [[Neanderthal]]s with ''[[Homo erectus]]'' in Asia. There is evidence of an early migration event 268,000 BCE within Neanderthal genetics,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Posth|first=Cosimo|last2=Wißing|first2=Christoph|last3=Kitagawa|first3=Keiko|last4=Pagani|first4=Luca|last5=Holstein|first5=Laura ===The Pacific (Australasia and Oceania)=== {{See also|Australian megafauna|List of extinct animals of the Hawaiian Islands|List of extinct animals of New Zealand}}In [[Australia (continent)|Sahul]] (a former continent composed of [[Fauna of Australia|Australia]] and [[Fauna of New Guinea|New Guinea]]), the sudden and extensive spate of extinctions occurred earlier than in the rest of the world.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=qIDC7ybvHQEC&pg=PA622&lpg=PA622&dq=Phascolomys+medius#v=onepage&q=Phascolomys%20medius&f=false|title=Quaternary Extinctions: A Prehistoric Revolution|last=Martin|first=Paul S.|last2=Klein|first2=Richard G.|date=1989-01-01|publisher=University of Arizona Press|isbn=9780816511006}}</ref><ref name="Lourandos2">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=tTy-I8no1MwC&pg=PA99&lpg=PA99&dq=Phascolomys+medius#v=onepage&q=Phascolomys%20medius&f=false|title=Continent of Hunter-Gatherers: New Perspectives in Australian Prehistory|last=Lourandos|first=Harry|date=1997-02-28|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9780521359467}}</ref><ref name="MacPhee2">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=UZLuF1YXYTcC&pg=PA251&dq=Euryzygoma#v=onepage&q=troposodon&f=false|title=Extinctions in Near Time|last=MacPhee|first=R. D. E.|date=1999-06-30|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=9780306460920}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=LwMkO0M1mPQC&pg=PA116&lpg=PA116&dq=Warendja+wakefieldi#v=onepage&q=Warendja%20wakefieldi&f=false|title=Prehistoric Mammals of Australia and New Guinea: One Hundred Million Years of Evolution|last=Long|first=John A.|last2=Archer|first2=Michael|date=2002-01-01|publisher=UNSW Press|isbn=9780868404356}}</ref><ref name="Tyndale-Biscoe2">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=YALY-B6s7IEC&pg=PA269&lpg=PA269&dq=Warendja+wakefieldi#v=onepage&q=Warendja%20wakefieldi&f=false|title=Life of Marsupials|last=Tyndale-Biscoe|first=Hugh|date=2005-04-22|publisher=Csiro Publishing|isbn=9780643099210}}</ref> Most evidence points to a 20,000 year period after human arrival circa 63,000 BCE,<ref name=":22" /> but scientific argument continues as to the exact date range.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=C0blLvmdp04C&pg=PA279&lpg=PA279&dq=Phascolomys+medius#v=onepage&q=Phascolomys%20medius&f=false|title=Corridors to Extinction and the Australian Megafauna|last=Webb|first=Steve|date=2013-02-27|publisher=Newnes|isbn=9780124078406}}</ref> In the rest of the Pacific (other [[Australasian ecozone|Australasian]] islands such as New Caledonia, and [[Oceania ecozone|Oceania]]) although in some respects far later, endemic fauna also usually perished quickly upon the arrival of humans in the late Pleistocene and early Holocene. This section does not include any spate of extinctions post 1000 BCE (e.g. [[subatlantic]] [[List of extinct animals of New Zealand|New Zealand]] or [[List of extinct animals of the Hawaiian Islands|Hawaii]]).
The extinctions in the Pacific included: * Various members of ''[[Diprotodontidae]]'' ** ''[[Diprotodon]]'' sp. (giant relatives of the [[wombat]]s) ** ''[[Euowenia]]'' sp. (diprotodont) ** ''[[Euryzygoma]] dunense'' (diprotodont) ** ''[[Hulitherium]] tomasetti'' (diprotodont) ** ''[[Maokopia]] ronaldi'' (diprotodont) ** ''[[Nototherium]] sp.'' (diprotodont) ** ''[[Zygomaturus]]'' sp. (a "marsupial rhino") * Various members of ''[[Macropodidae]]'' ** ''[[Macropus]] sp. (giant Australian terrestrial crocodile) ** ''[[Volia]]'' (a two-to-three meter long [[Mekosuchinae|mekosuchine]] crocodylian, apex predator of Pleistocene Fiji) * ''[[Meiolania]]'' et ''[[Ninjemys]]'' (giant armoured tortoises) * Giant Iguana (''[[Lapitiguana]]'' et ''[[Brachylophus gibbonsi]]'') * Pygmy Cassowary (''[[Casuarius lydekkeri]]'') * ''[[Genyornis|Genyornis newtoni]]'' (a three meter tall [[Dromornithidae|dromornthid]], often referred to in vernacular as 'the last thunder bird') * [[Powerful goshawk]] and the [[Gracile goshawk]] (''Accipiter efficax et Accipiter quartus'')<sup>[[Accipiter|[3]]]</sup> * ''[[Sylviornis]]'' (giant, flightless [[New Caledonia]]n [[Galliformes|galliform]]- largest in existence) * [[Noble megapode]] (''Megavitornis altirostris'') * [[New Caledonian gallinule]] (''Porphyrio kukwiedei'') * Giant [[megapode]]s ** [[Giant malleefowl]] (''Leipoa gallinacea'') ** [[Pile-builder megapode]] (''Megapodius molistructor'') ** [[Consumed scrubfowl]] (''Megapodius alimentum'') ** [[Viti Levu scrubfowl]] (''Megapodius amissus'') * [[New Caledonian ground dove]] (''Gallicolumba longitarsus'') * [[New Caledonian snipe]] et [[Viti Levu snipe]] (''Coenocorypha miratropica'' et ''Coenocorypha neocaledonica'') * [[Niue night heron]] (''Nycticorax kalavikai'') * [[Marquesas cuckoo-dove]] (''Macropygia heana'') * [[New Caledonian barn owl]] (''Tyto letocarti'') * Various ''[[Gallirallus|Galliraillus]]'' sp. * [[Kaua'i mole duck]] (''Talpanas lippa'', a blind, flightless, terrestrial Hawaiian duck) * ''[[Apteribis]]'' (a giant, flightless ibis) * [[Lowland kagu]] (''Rhynochetos orarius'') * [[Viti Levu giant pigeon]] (''Natunaornis gigoura'') * [[American flamingo|American Flamingo]] (''Phoenicopterus ruber,'' [[Local extinction|extirpated]] in Australia)<ref name=":112">{{Cite book|last=Bayly|first=I. a. [[File:Mamut_lanudo.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Mamut_lanudo.jpg|thumb|253x253px|The [[woolly mammoth]] became extinct around [[10th millennium BC|10,000 BCE]] – except for diminutive relict populations on [[Saint Paul Island (Alaska)|St. Paul Island]] and [[Wrangel Island]], which humans did not colonise until [[30th century BC|3,600 BCE]] and [[2nd millennium BC|2,000 BCE]] respectively.]] [[File:Ursus_spelaeus_Sergiodlarosa.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Ursus_spelaeus_Sergiodlarosa.jpg|thumb|250x250px|Cave bear (''[[Cave bear|Ursus spelaeus]]'')]] [[File:Elephasantiquus.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Elephasantiquus.jpg|thumb|250x250px|Models of the [[straight-tusked elephant]] (''Paleoloxodon antiquus'').]] [[File:Elasm062.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Elasm062.jpg|thumb|249x249px|''[[Elasmotherium]]'' reconstruction]] [[File:Hippopotamus_amphibius_Whipsnade_Zoo.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Hippopotamus_amphibius_Whipsnade_Zoo.jpg|thumb|248x248px|[[Hippopotamus (genus)|Hippopotamuses]] (''Hippopotamus'' sp.) inhabited [[Great Britain]] until 80,000 BCE, whence due to glacial shifts, hippopotamuses were restricted to [[Southern Europe|Southern-Eastern Europe]], [[Mediterranean Sea|Mediterranean islands]] and finally [[Western Asia]] until 1,000 BCE.]] Some extinct megafauna, such as the [[bunyip]]-like ''[[Diprotodon]]'', may remain in [[folk memory]] or be the sources of [[Cryptozoology|cryptozoological legends]].
===Europe and Northern Eurasia=== [[File:ZOO_Olomouc07_Panthera_pardus_orientalis.JPG|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:ZOO_Olomouc07_Panthera_pardus_orientalis.JPG|thumb|243x243px|The [[Leopard]] (''Panthera pardus'') inhabited the entire expanse of [[Afro-Eurasia]] below the [[54th parallel north]], from modern day [[Spain]] and the [[United Kingdom|UK]] in the west, to [[South Africa]] in the south, and [[Siberia]], [[Japan]] and [[Sundaland]] in the east during the Late Pleistocene.]] This geography spans the entirety of the [[Continental Europe|European continent]], and stretches into [[North Asia|Northern Asia]], through the [[Caucasus]] and [[Central Asia]] to [[North China|Northern China]], [[Siberia]] and [[Beringia]]. During the [[Late Pleistocene]], this region was noted for its great diversity and dynamism of [[biome]]s, including the warm climes of the [[Mediterranean Basin|Mediterranean basin]], open [[Woodland|temperate woodlands]], [[Plain|arid plains]], [[Heath|mountainous heathland]] and [[swamp]]y [[wetland]]s, all of which were vulnerable to the severe climatic fluctuations of the interchanges between glacial and interglacials periods ([[stadial]]s). However, it was the expansive [[mammoth steppe]] which was the [[Ecoregion|ecosystem]] which united and defined this region during the Late Pleistocene.<ref name=":62">{{Cite journal|last=Kahlke|first=Ralf-Dietrich|date=2014|title=The origin of Eurasian Mammoth Faunas (''Mammuthus''-''Coelodonta'' Faunal Complex)|url=http://www.rhinoresourcecenter.com/pdf_files/140/1404659577.pdf|journal=Quaternary Science Reviews|volume=96|pages=32–49|bibcode=2014QSRv...96...32K|doi=10.1016/j.quascirev.2013.01.012}}</ref> One of the key features of Europe's Late Pleistocene climate was the often [[Turnover-pulse hypothesis|drastic turnover of conditions and biota]] between the numerous stadials, which could set within a century. For example, during glacial periods, the entire [[North Sea]] was drained of water to form [[Doggerland]]. The final major cold spell occurred from 25,000 BCE to 18,000 BCE, and is known as the [[Last Glacial Maximum]], when the Fenno-Scandinavian ice sheet covered much of [[Last Glacial Maximum refugia|northern Europe]], while the Alpine ice sheet occupied significant parts of central-southern Europe.
Europe, and in particular northern Eurasia, being [[Ice age#Positive and negative feedback in glacial periods|far colder and drier]] than today,<ref name="Zimov 26–452">{{Cite journal|last=Zimov|first=S. A.|last2=Zimov|first2=N. S.|last3=Tikhonov|first3=A. N.|last4=Chapin III|first4=F. S.|date=2012-12-04|title=Mammoth steppe: a high-productivity phenomenon|journal=Quaternary Science Reviews|volume=57|pages=26–45|bibcode=2012QSRv...57...26Z|doi=10.1016/j.quascirev.2012.10.005}}</ref> was largely [[Ecoregion|hegemonized]] by the [[mammoth steppe]], an [[ecosystem]] dominated by palatable [[Productivity (ecology)|high-productivity]] [[Poaceae|grasses]], [[Herbaceous plant|herbs]] and [[Willow|willow shrubs]].<ref name="Zimov 26–452" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sher|first=A. V.|last2=Kuzmina|first2=S. A.|last3=Kuznetsova|first3=T. V.|last4=Sulerzhitsky|first4=L. D.|date=2005-03-01|title=New insights into the Weichselian environment and climate of the East Siberian Arctic, derived from fossil insects, plants, and mammals|journal=Quaternary Science Reviews|volume=24|issue=5–6|pages=533–569|bibcode=2005QSRv...24..533S|doi=10.1016/j.quascirev.2004.09.007}}</ref> This supported an [[Species richness|extensive biota]] of [[Steppe|grassland]] fauna, and stretched eastwards from [[Spain]] in the [[Iberian Peninsula]] to the [[Yukon]] in modern-day [[Canada]].<ref name=":62" /><ref name="Zimov 26–452" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Adams|first=J. M.|last2=Faure|first2=H.|last3=Faure-Denard|first3=L.|last4=McGlade|first4=J. M.|last5=Woodward|first5=F. I.|date=1990-12-27|title=Increases in terrestrial carbon storage from the Last Glacial Maximum to the present|journal=Nature|volume=348|issue=6303|pages=711–714|bibcode=1990Natur.348..711A|doi=10.1038/348711a0}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Álvarez-Lao|first=Diego J.|last2=García|first2=Nuria|date=2011-03-15|title=Geographical distribution of Pleistocene cold-adapted large mammal faunas in the Iberian Peninsula|journal=Quaternary International|series=Quaternary Floral and Faunal Assemblages: Ecological and Taphonomical Investigations|volume=233|issue=2|pages=159–170|bibcode=2011QuInt.233..159A|doi=10.1016/j.quaint.2010.04.017}}</ref> The area was populated by many species of [[grazers]] which assembled in large herds similar in size to those in Africa today. Populous species which roamed the great grasslands included the [[woolly mammoth]], [[woolly rhinoceros]], ''[[Elasmotherium]]'', [[Steppe wisent|steppe bison]], [[Equus (genus)|Pleistocene horse]], [[muskox]], ''[[Cervalces latifrons|Cervalces]]'', [[reindeer]], [[antelope]] (''Parabubalis, [[Mongolian gazelle|Procapra]], [[Saiga antelope|Saiga]], Spirocerus'') and [[steppe pika]]. Carnivores included [[Panthera leo spelaea|cave lion]], ''[[Homotherium]]'', [[cave hyena]], [[grey wolf]], [[dhole]], and the [[arctic fox]].<ref name="Hoffecker2">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=DQkpVuA7_6UC&pg=PA56&lpg=PA56&dq=baikal+yak#v=onepage&q=baikal%20yak&f=false|title=Human Ecology of Beringia|last=Hoffecker|first=John F.|last2=Elias|first2=Scott A.|date=2012-05-29|publisher=Columbia University Press|isbn=9780231503884}}</ref><ref name=":72">{{Cite journal|last=Vereshchagin|first=N. K.|last2=Baryshnikov|first2=G. F.|date=1991-01-01|title=The ecological structure of the "Mammoth Fauna" in Eurasia|journal=Annales Zoologici Fennici|volume=28|issue=3/4|pages=253–259|jstor=23735450}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=qIDC7ybvHQEC&pg=PA489&lpg=PA489&dq=parabubalis+capricornis#v=onepage&q=parabubalis%20capricornis&f=false|title=Quaternary Extinctions: A Prehistoric Revolution|last=Martin|first=Paul S.|last2=Klein|first2=Richard G.|date=1989-01-01|publisher=University of Arizona Press|isbn=9780816511006}}</ref>
At the edges of these large stretches of grassland could be found more [[Shrub-steppe|shrub-like]] terrain and [[Cold semi-arid climate|dry]] [[Pinophyta|conifer]] [[forest]]s and [[woodland]] (akin to [[forest steppe]] or [[taiga]]). The browsing collective of megafauna included [[woolly rhinoceros]], [[Giant deer]], [[moose]], ''[[Cervalces latifrons|Cervalces]]'', [[tarpan]], [[aurochs]], [[Bison|woodland bison]], [[camel]]s and smaller deer (''[[Siberian roe deer|Capreolus]]'', ''[[Cervus]]'', ''[[Siberian musk deer|Moschus]]''). [[Brown bear]]s, [[wolverine]]s, [[cave bear]], [[Gray wolf|wolves]], [[lynx]], [[leopard]]s, and [[red fox]]es also inhabited this biome. [[Tiger]]s were at stages also present, from the edges of [[Eastern Europe]] around the [[Black Sea]] to [[Beringia]]. The more [[Montane ecosystems|mountainous terrain]], incorporating [[Montane grasslands and shrublands|montane grasslands]], [[Subalpine zone|subalpine conifer forests]], [[alpine tundra]] and [[Schrofen|broken, craggy slopes]], was occupied by several species of mountain-going animals like [[argali]], [[chamois]], [[Capra (genus)|ibex]], [[mouflon]], [[pika]], [[Gray wolf|wolves]], [[leopard]]s, [[Ursus (genus)|''Ursus sp.'']] and [[lynx]], with [[snow leopard]]s, Baikal yak and [[snow sheep]] in [[North Asia|Northern Asia]]. [[Arctic tundra]], which lined the north of the mammoth steppe, reflected modern ecology with species such as the [[polar bear]], [[Tundra wolf|wolf]], [[reindeer]] and [[muskox]].
Other biomes, although less noted, were significant in contributing to the diversity of fauna in Late Pleistocene Europe. Warmer grasslands such as [[Temperate grasslands, savannas, and shrublands|temperate steppes]] and [[Mediterranean forests, woodlands, and scrub|Mediterranean savannahs]] hosted ''[[Stephanorhinus]],'' [[gazelle]], [[European bison]], [[Asian ostrich]]es, ''[[Leptobos]]'', [[cheetah]]s, and [[onager]]. These biomes also contained an assortment of mammoth steppe fauna, such as [[saiga antelope]], [[History of lions in Europe|lions]], ''[[Homotherium]]'', [[cave hyena]]s, [[Gray wolf|wolves]], [[Equus (genus)|Pleistocene horse]], [[steppe bison]], ''Spirocerus,'' [[aurochs]], and [[camel]]s. [[Temperate coniferous forest|Temperate coniferous]], [[Temperate deciduous forest|deciduous]], [[Temperate broadleaf and mixed forest|mixed broadleaf]] and [[Mediterranean forests, woodlands, and scrub|Mediterranean forests and open woodlands]] accommodated [[straight-tusked elephant]]s, ''[[Praemegaceros]]'', ''[[Stephanorhinus]]'', [[wild boar]], bovids such as [[European bison]], [[tahr]] and [[West Caucasian tur|tur]], species of ''[[Ursus (genus)|Ursus]]'' such as the [[Ursus etruscus|Etruscan bear]], and smaller deer (''[[Roe deer|Capreolus]],'' ''[[Red deer|Cervus]],'' ''[[Fallow deer|Dama]], Haploidoceros'') with several mammoth steppe species, such as [[lynx]], [[tarpan]], [[Gray wolf|wolves]], [[dhole]]s, [[moose]], [[Giant deer]], [[Bison|woodland bison]], [[leopard]]s, and [[aurochs]]. [[Woolly rhinoceros]] and [[Woolly mammoth|mammoth]] occasionally resided in these temperate biomes, mixing with predominately temperate fauna to escape harsh glacials.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/tetrapod-zoology/the-remarkable-life-appearance-of-the-woolly-rhino/|title=The remarkable life appearance of the Woolly rhino|last=Naish|first=Darren|work=Scientific American Blog Network|access-date=2017-04-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rhinoresourcecenter.com/index.php?s=1&act=pdfviewer&id=1402660443&folder=140|title=New discoveries of woolly mammoth and woolly rhinoceros from Northern Iberia|last=Diego J. ÁLVAREZ-LAO|first=|date=|website=Scientific Annals, School of Geology, Aristotle University of Thessaloniki|publisher=Greece VIth International Conference on Mammoths and their Relatives, Special Volume 102|access-date=2017-04-16}}</ref> In warmer [[wetland]]s, [[Bubalus murrensis|European water buffalo]] and [[Hippopotamus antiquus|hippopotamus]] were present. Although these habitats were restricted to [[Refugium (population biology)|micro refugia]] and to [[Southern Europe]] and its fringes, being in [[Iberian Peninsula|Iberia]], [[Italy]], the [[Balkans]], [[Geography of Ukraine|Ukraine's]] [[Black Sea]] [[Pontic–Caspian steppe|basin]], the [[Caucasus]], and [[Western Asia]], during inter-glacials these biomes had a far more northernly range. For example, [[hippopotamus]] inhabited [[Great Britain]] and [[straight-tusked elephant]] the [[The Netherlands|Netherlands]], as recently as 80,000 BCE and 42,000 BCE respectively.<ref name=":52" /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/264785182|title=Patterns of Late Quaternary megafaunal extinctions in Europe and northern Asia (PDF Download Available)|website=ResearchGate|access-date=2017-03-28}}</ref>
The first possible indications of habitation by hominins are the 7.2 million year old finds of ''[[Graecopithecus]]'',<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Fuss|first=Jochen|last2=Spassov|first2=Nikolai|last3=Begun|first3=David R.|last4=Böhme|first4=Madelaine|date=2017-05-22|title=Potential hominin affinities of Graecopithecus from the Late Miocene of Europe|journal=PLOS ONE|volume=12|issue=5|pages=e0177127|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0177127|pmid=28531170|pmc=5439669|issn=1932-6203|bibcode=2017PLoSO..1277127F}}</ref> and 5.7 million year old footprints in Crete — however established habitation is noted in Georgia from 1.8 million years ago, proceeded to Germany and France, by ''[[Homo erectus#Descendants and subspecies|Homo erectus]]''.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gierliński|first=Gerard D.|last2=Niedźwiedzki|first2=Grzegorz|last3=Lockley|first3=Martin G.|last4=Athanassiou|first4=Athanassios|last5=Fassoulas|first5=Charalampos|last6=Dubicka|first6=Zofia|last7=Boczarowski|first7=Andrzej|last8=Bennett|first8=Matthew R.|last9=Ahlberg|first9=Per Erik|title=Possible hominin footprints from the late Miocene (c. 5.7 Ma) of Crete?|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S001678781730113X|journal=Proceedings of the Geologists' Association|doi=10.1016/j.pgeola.2017.07.006|volume=128|issue=5–6|year=2017|pages=697–710}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/deadthings/2017/09/01/what-made-these-footprints-5-7-million-years-ago/#.WbYbeNN97Vp|title=What Made These Footprints 5.7 Million Years Ago? - Dead Things|date=2017-09-01|work=Dead Things|access-date=2017-09-18}}</ref> Prominent co-current and subsequent species include ''[[Homo antecessor]]'', ''[[Homo cepranensis]]'', ''[[Homo heidelbergensis]]'', [[Neanderthal]]s and [[Denisovan]]s, preceding human habitation circa 38,000 BCE.
Europe's Late Pleistocene biota went through two phases of extinction. Some fauna became extinct before 13,000 BCE, in staggered intervals, particularly between 50,000 BCE and 30,000 BCE. Species include [[cave bear]], ''[[Elasmotherium]]'', [[straight-tusked elephant]], ''[[Stephanorhinus]]'', [[Bubalus murrensis|water buffalo]], [[Neanderthal]]s, [[gazelle]], and ''[[Homotherium]]''. However, the great majority of species were [[Biodiversity loss|extinguished]], [[Local extinction|extirpated]] or experienced severe [[Population bottleneck|population contractions]] between 13,000 BCE and 9,000 BCE,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/figure/290991017_fig1_Figure-2-Summary-extinctions-chart-for-northern-Eurasia-Green-bars-show-the-known|title=. Summary extinctions chart for northern Eurasia. Green bars... – Figure 1 of 7|website=ResearchGate|access-date=2017-04-07}}</ref> ending with the [[Younger Dryas]]. At that time there were small ice sheets in [[Scotland]] and [[Scandinavia]]. The mammoth steppe [[Ecological collapse|disappeared]] from the vast majority of its former range, either due to a permanent shift in [[Ecological succession|climatic conditions]], or an absence of [[Ecosystem engineer|ecosystem management]] due to [[Ecological extinction|decimated]], [[Population fragmentation|fragmented]] or [[Biodiversity loss|extinct]] populations of [[Megafauna|megaherbivores]].<ref name="Owen-Smith19922">{{cite book|title=Megaherbivores: The influence of very large body size on ecology. Cambridge studies in ecology|author=Owen-Smith, R.N.|publisher=Cambridge Univ. Press|year=1992|isbn=978-0-521-42637-4|location=Cambridge}}</ref><ref name="WhitneySmith20062">{{cite book|title=Clovis and Extinctions – Overkill, Second Order Predation, Environmental Degradation in a Non-equilibrium Ecosystem "Clovis Age Continent"|author=Whitney-Smith, E.|publisher=University of New Mexico Press|year=2006}}</ref> This led to a [[Ecological threshold|region wide]] [[Extinction debt|extinction]] [[extinction vortex|vortex]], resulting in [[Density dependence|cyclically]] [[Carrying capacity|diminishing]] [[Productivity (ecology)|bio-productivity]]{{CN|date=October 2018}} and [[defaunation]]. [[Foster's rule|Insular]] species on [[List of islands in the Mediterranean|Mediterranean islands]] such as [[Sardinia]], [[Sicily]], [[Malta]], [[Cyprus]] and [[Crete]], went extinct around the same time as humans colonised those islands. Fauna included dwarf [[Dwarf elephant|elephantids]], [[Praemegaceros|megacerines]] and [[Hippopotamus (genus)|hippopotamuses]], and giant [[Cretan owl|avians]], [[Megalenhydris|otters]] and [[Leithia|rodents]].{{See also|List of extinct animals of Europe}} [[File:Lions_painting,_Chauvet_Cave_(museum_replica).jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Lions_painting,_Chauvet_Cave_(museum_replica).jpg|thumb|240x240px|The 'Gallery of Lions', representations of the [[Panthera leo spelaea|Eurasian Cave Lion]] in [[Chauvet Cave|Chauvet-Pont-d'Arc Cave]].]] [[File:Homotherium_serum_life-restoration.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Homotherium_serum_life-restoration.jpg|thumb|232x232px|''[[Homotherium]]'' restoration.]] [[File:Wild_horse_reconstruction.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Wild_horse_reconstruction.jpg|thumb|233x233px|Reconstruction of the five [[phenotype]]s of [[Tarpan|Pleistocene wild horse]]. The coat colours and dimensions are based on genetic evidence and historic descriptions.]] [[File:Homo_neanderthalensis_adult_male_-_head_model_-_Smithsonian_Museum_of_Natural_History_-_2012-05-17.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Homo_neanderthalensis_adult_male_-_head_model_-_Smithsonian_Museum_of_Natural_History_-_2012-05-17.jpg|thumb|322x322px|A model of an adult [[Neanderthal]] male head and shoulders on display in the Hall of Human Origins in the [[National Museum of Natural History]] in [[Washington, D.C.]]]] [[File:Iranian_Cheetah_roars.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Iranian_Cheetah_roars.jpg|thumb|237x237px|Modern cheetah (''[[Cheetah|Acinonyx jubatus]]'') replaced giant cheetah (''[[Giant cheetah|Acinonyx pardinensis]]'') in Eurasia after the [[Middle Pleistocene]], and inhabited a range from [[Eastern Europe]] and [[Balkans|the Balkans]] to [[China]]. Today, the [[critically endangered]] [[Asiatic cheetah|Eurasian cheetah]] are now restricted to [[Iran]].]] [[File:Saiga.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Saiga.jpg|thumb|[[Saiga antelope]] (''Saiga sp.'') inhabited a range from [[Great Britain|England]] and [[France]] to [[Yukon|the Yukon]] in the Late Pleistocene, diversifying into two species. ''S. borealis'' is now extinct and the [[critically endangered]] ''[[Saiga antelope|S. tatarica]]'' is now limited to [[Eurasian Steppe|steppe]] in [[Kazakhstan]] and [[Mongolia]].]] (80,000–4,000 years ago) * [[Woolly mammoth]] (''Mammuthus primigenius'') * [[Dwarf elephant|Dwarf Mammoth]] ** Cretan Dwarf Mammoth (''[[Mammuthus creticus]]'') ** Dwarf Sardinian Mammoth (''[[Mammuthus lamarmorai]]'') * [[Straight-tusked elephant|Straight Tusked Elephant]] (''Palaeoloxodon antiquus'') * [[Palaeoloxodon namadicus|Asian Straight Tusked Elephant]] (''Paleoloxodon namadicus'', [[North Asia|Northern Asia]])<ref name=":52" /> * [[Dwarf elephant|Dwarf Elephant]] ** ''[[Palaeoloxodon chaniensis]]'' ** ''[[Cyprus Dwarf Elephant|Palaeoloxodon cypriotes]]'' ** ''[[Palaeoloxodon falconeri]]'' ** ''[[Palaeoloxodon mnaidriensis]]'' * ''[[Pika|Ochotona]]'' sp. (e.g. [[Giant pika]] (''O. whartoni'')) * [[Woolly rhinoceros]] (''Coelodonta antiquitatis'') * ''[[Stephanorhinus]]'' sp. (e.g. ** [[Wild horse|Wild Horse]] (''[[Wild horse#Subspecies and their history|E. ferus ssp.]]'') ** ''Equus [[Open nomenclature|cf.]] galllicus''<ref name="researchgate.net2">{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/263278368|title=Late quaternary equids (genus Equus) of South-western and South-central Siberia (PDF Download Available)|website=ResearchGate|access-date=2017-04-17}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=XTPbVI5Gf6MC&pg=PA146&lpg=PA146&dq=equus+gallicus#v=onepage&q=equus%20gallicus&f=false|title=The Cave of Fontéchevade: Recent Excavations and Their Paleoanthropological Implications|last=Chase|first=Philip G.|date=2009-01-01|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9780521898447}}</ref> ** [[European ass|European Ass]] (''E. hydruntinus'') ** [[File:Hippidion_principale_skull.JPG|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Hippidion_principale_skull.JPG|thumb|210x210px|Fossil skull of ''[[Hippidion]]'', a genera of native South American horse of a [[Phorusrhacidae|phorusrhacid]] in [[Geography of Uruguay|Uruguay]] are similar in size to the above Pliocene age ''[[Procariama|Procariama simplex]]''.]] During the last 60,000 years, including the end of the [[last glacial period]], approximately 51 genera of large mammals have become extinct in [[North America]]. Of these, many genera extinctions can be reliably attributed to a brief interval of 11,500 to 10,000 [[radiocarbon]] years [[before present]], shortly following the arrival of the [[Clovis people]] in North America. Prominent paleontological sites include Mexico,<ref name=":32">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/1002234186|title=Human origin sites and the World Heritage Convention in AmericasnVolume 1|others=Sanz, Nuria|isbn=9789231001406|volume=1|location=Paris|oclc=1002234186}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=wBcxDgAAQBAJ&pg=PA550&lpg=PA550&dq=Plyolimbus+baryosteus#v=onepage&q=Plyolimbus%20baryosteus&f=false|title=The Oxford Handbook of Zooarchaeology|last=Albarella|first=Umberto|last2=Rizzetto|first2=Mauro|last3=Russ|first3=Hannah|last4=Viner-Daniels|first4=Sarah|date=2017|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780199686476}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Palma-Ramírez|first=Arturo|last2=Goyenechea|first2=Irene|last3=Castillo-Cerón|first3=Jesús M.|date=2014-12-01|title=Panbiogeography of the Santa María Amajac area, Hidalgo, Mexico|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1870345314730052|journal=Revista Mexicana de Biodiversidad|volume=85|issue=4|pages=1228–1234|doi=10.7550/rmb.44392}}</ref> [https://www.uv.mx/personal/tcarmona/files/2010/08/Arroyo-et-al-2008.pdf <nowiki>[1]</nowiki>] and Panama, the crossroads of the [[Great American Interchange|American Interchange]].[https://azueroearthproject.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/A.B4000_Pearson_2005_eng.pdf <nowiki>[2]</nowiki>] Most other extinctions are poorly constrained in time, though some definitely occurred outside of this narrow interval.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Anthony D. Barnosky|author2=Paul L. Koch|author3=Robert S. Feranec|author4=Scott L. Wing|author5=Alan B. Shabel|year=2004|title=Assessing the Causes of Late Pleistocene Extinctions on the Continents|journal=Science|volume=306|issue=5693|pages=70–75|bibcode=2004Sci...306...70B|doi=10.1126/science.1101476|pmid=15459379|citeseerx=10.1.1.574.332}}</ref> In contrast, only about half a dozen small mammals disappeared during this time. Previous North American extinction pulses had occurred at the end of glaciations, but not with such an ecological imbalance between large mammals and small ones. (Moreover, previous extinction pulses were not comparable to the Quaternary extinction event; they involved primarily species replacements within ecological niches, while the latter event resulted in many ecological niches being left unoccupied). Such include the last native North American terror bird (''[[Titanis]]''), rhinoceros (''[[Aphelops]]'') and hyena (''[[Chasmaporthetes]]''). Human habitation commenced unequivacolly approximately 22,000 BCE north of the glacier,<ref name=":1" /> and 13,500 BCE south,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Waters|first=Michael R.|last2=Forman|first2=Steven L.|last3=Jennings|first3=Thomas A.|last4=Nordt|first4=Lee C.|last5=Driese|first5=Steven G.|last6=Feinberg|first6=Joshua M.|last7=Keene|first7=Joshua L.|last8=Halligan|first8=Jessi|last9=Lindquist|first9=Anna|date=2011-03-25|title=The Buttermilk Creek Complex and the Origins of Clovis at the Debra L. Friedkin Site, Texas|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/331/6024/1599|journal=Science|volume=331|issue=6024|pages=1599–1603|doi=10.1126/science.1201855|pmid=21436451|issn=0036-8075|bibcode=2011Sci...331.1599W}}</ref><ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/28/world/americas/discoveries-challenge-beliefs-on-humans-arrival-in-the-americas.html|title=Discoveries Challenge Beliefs on Humans’ Arrival in the Americas|last=Romero|first=Simon|date=2014-03-27|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-09-16|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> however disputed evidence of southern human habitation exists from 130,000 BCE and 17,000 BCE onwards, described from sites in California and [[Meadowcroft Rockshelter|Meadowcroft]] in [[Pennsylvania]].<ref name=":32" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/2017/04/mastodons-americas-peopling-migrations-archaeology-science/|title=Humans in California 130,000 Years Ago? Get the Facts|date=2017-04-26|access-date=2017-09-15}}</ref> The megafaunal extinctions include forty one genera of herbivores ('''H'''), and twenty carnivores ('''C''').
