[[Pào Chuí]] (''MK:A'') }} }} '''Reptile''' is a [[Playable character|video game character]] from the ''[[Mortal Kombat]]'' fighting game franchise created for [[Midway Games]] by [[Ed Boon]] and [[John Tobias]]. He debuted in ''[[Mortal Kombat (1992 video game)|Mortal Kombat]]'' as a hidden opponent and appeared in subsequent titles as a playable character, also appearing in the merchandise and other media related to the series. Reptile is a Raptor, a nearly-extinct [[bipedal]] [[Reptilian humanoid|humanoid race of reptilian creatures]] and loyally serves the series' recurring villain [[Shao Kahn]] in hope that his race will be revived. Reptile has been featured in almost every title in the series under the same pretenses, and until the [[Mortal Kombat (2011 video game)|2011 reboot]], he had yet to be rewarded for his efforts. Critical reception to the character has been positive, with many print and online publications commenting on his evolution since his debut as a hidden character. ==Conception and history== [[File:MK4 Reptile.png|thumb|left|upright|Originally a [[palette swap]] of [[Scorpion (Mortal Kombat)|Scorpion]], Reptile's design evolved as the series progressed.]] Included in the first game late in the development process, Reptile's character concept was conceived while Boon was driving back to work from lunch. Noting the success of utilizing a [[palette swap]] method for [[Scorpion (Mortal Kombat)|Scorpion]] and [[Sub-Zero (Mortal Kombat)|Sub-Zero's]] character sprites,{{cite video game|title=[[Mortal Kombat: Armageddon]] |developer=Midway |publisher=Midway |date=2006-10-11 |level=Reptile Kombat Card video}} he and Tobias decided to include a "super secret hidden feature" in ''Mortal Kombat'', choosing Reptile's green color as a contrast to Scorpion's original yellow and Sub-Zero's blue colors.Kent, Steve L. (2001). ''The Ultimate History of Video Games''. [[Prima Games]]. {{ISBN|0-7615-3643-4}}. p. 463 Developed with the premise of being "a cooler version of Scorpion", the character's concept was completed in a single evening.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bt2bdW5vagY TMK E308 - MK vs DCU - Ed Boon interview Part 1], (YouTube, [http://www.totalmortalkombat.com/mkvsdcu/e32008/edboon08transcript.txt interview transcript]). Total Mortal Kombat. Retrieved on 2008-12-26 Reptile's inclusion was intended as a marketing tool for the arcade game: as extreme conditions must be met to encounter Reptile, the designers hoped to rely on word of mouth to spread rumors of the character's existence.{{cite book |author=Kent, Steve L. |title=The First Quarter: A 25-year History of Video Games|year=2000 |publisher=BWD Press |page=370 |isbn=0-9704755-0-0}} However, the character was not included in the title until version 3.0 of the game.{{cite web|url= http://www.gamespot.com/gamespot/features/video/hist_mortalk/p13.html |title=The History of Mortal Kombat - Mortal Kombat (1992)|publisher=[[GameSpot]]|author1=Greeson, Jeff |author2=O'Neill, Cliff |lastauthoramp=yes |accessdate=2008-12-25|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071021084618/http://www.gamespot.com/gamespot/features/video/hist_mortalk/p13.html|archivedate=2007-10-21}} Reptile's appearance caused fans to speculate that he could be unlocked and used as a controllable character. Boon noted in a later interview that due to the popularity of the rumors surrounding the character, they decided to include Reptile in subsequent installments of the series as a playable fighter.{{cite video game|title=[[Mortal Kombat 3]] |developer=Midway |publisher=Midway |date=1995 |level=Ed Boon and John Tobias interview}} ===Design=== Reptile was originally depicted as a tall, muscular, light-skinned humanoid. Due to his origin as a palette swap of [[Scorpion (Mortal Kombat)|Scorpion]] and [[Sub-Zero (Mortal Kombat)|Sub-Zero]], his attire was identical to theirs only colored in green. His clothing consists of pants and boots covering his lower body, along with a black sleeveless shirt and open hood. Green light armor covered his forearms and lower legs, while an open V-shaped green vest protected his torso, extending to a matching small [[Faulds (plate armour)|fauld]] and loincloth. He wears a green facial mask as part of his [[ninja]] disguise to conceal his true reptilian nature, however he does remove the mask in-game for his [[Acid]] Spit attack or his [[tongue]] grab fatality.{{cite book |author=Wartow, Ronald |title=Official Ultimate Mortal Kombat 3 Fighter's Kompanion|year=1996 |publisher=[[BradyGames]]|page=370 |isbn=1-56686-639-1}} Reptile stands 6 feet (183 cm) tall, and speaks in a hissing tone. In ''[[Mortal Kombat 4]]'', Reptile's appearance became more reptilian, with his head completely uncovered. His hands became clawed, while his feet were now three-toed talons. By ''[[Mortal Kombat: Deadly Alliance|Deadly Alliance]]'', Reptile had developed a full reptilian head and tail, with gold and black armor to cover his legs, elbows, shoulders, and belt, and he was competely barefoot. Bone spurs extended from the base of his [[skull]] down his spine, ending at the tip of his tail, while a similar spur extended from his heel on each bare foot. Ed Boon described the changes to Reptile's design over the course of the two games as hinting at him "evolving into a bigger character", and foreshadowing Onaga controlling his body in ''[[Mortal Kombat: Deception|Deception]]''. Reptile's appearance in ''[[Mortal Kombat: Shaolin Monks|Shaolin Monks]]'' used an amalgam of his three previous designs, intended by character designer Mark Lappin to portray a classic yet fresh feel for the character. The design incorporated the appearance of his body from ''Mortal Kombat 4'', his clothing from the original ''Mortal Kombat'', and the look of his bare feet, hands, and armor from ''Deadly Alliance''. In addition, black strips of cloth wrapped around his forearms, hands, and head, leaving his eyes,mouth and bare feet exposed.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060528175615/http://www.gameinformer.com/News/Media/Media.htm?CS_pid=%7B7C3D28D1-B78E-459B-9C48-86481FE2EF9D%7D |archivedate=2006-05-28 |url=http://www.gameinformer.com/News/Media/Media.htm?CS_pid={7C3D28D1-B78E-459B-9C48-86481FE2EF9D} |title=Mortal Kombat: Shaolin Monks Media |publisher=''[[Game Informer]]'' |accessdate=2008-12-26 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The design was later reused as his primary outfit in ''[[Mortal Kombat: Armageddon|Armageddon]]'', with his appearance from ''Deadly Alliance'' serving as his secondary outfit. ==Appearances== ===In video games=== In the original ''Mortal Kombat'', Reptile is a mysterious hidden enemy character, unplayable and with no biography.{{cite news |first=Chip |last=Carter |author2= Jonathan, Carter|title= They are just dying to talk about Mortal Kombat |page=5D |date= 1994-02-07 |newspaper=[[St. Petersburg Times]] }} Hints regarding the conditions of how to unlock the fight against him are conveyed by Reptile randomly appearing prior to other matches. Some of these hints include "Look to La Luna," "Perfection is the key," and "Alone is how to find me." To fight Reptile, the player must get a Double Flawless victory in single player mode on the Pit stage and finish the match off with a fatality, all without blocking. There must also be a silhouette flying past the moon, which will occur every sixth game. In ''[[Mortal Kombat II]]'', Reptile returns as a playable character and a member of a reptilian race called Raptors,{{cite video game|title=[[Mortal Kombat: Armageddon]] |developer=Midway |publisher=Midway |platform=[[Wii]] |date=2007-07-15 |level=Fighter of the Wiik: Khameleon}} who were pulled into Outworld and enslaved by [[Shao Kahn]]. Promised the revival of his people in turn for his loyalty, Reptile serves Kahn as [[Shang Tsung]]'s bodyguard.{{cite video game|title=[[Mortal Kombat II]] |developer=Midway |publisher=Midway |date=1993 |level=Reptile ending}} He was chosen to assist Jade in order to kill [[Kitana (Mortal Kombat)|Kitana]] during the events of ''[[Ultimate Mortal Kombat 3]]'',{{cite video game|title=[[Ultimate Mortal Kombat 3]] |developer=Midway |publisher=Midway |date=1995 |level=Reptile ending}} he is defeated and exiled, but reappears in ''[[Mortal Kombat 4]]'' as [[List of Mortal Kombat characters#Shinnok|Shinnok]]{{'}}s minion.{{cite video game|title=[[Mortal Kombat 4]] |developer=Midway |publisher=Midway |date=1997-10-15 |level=Reptile ending}} By ''[[Mortal Kombat: Deadly Alliance|Deadly Alliance]]'', Reptile returns to Kahn's service. He overhears Shang Tsung plotting to kill Kahn, but en route to warn his master, he meets [[List of characters in the Mortal Kombat series#Nitara|a female vampire]] who offers knowledge of his race.{{cite video game|title=[[Mortal Kombat: Deadly Alliance]] |developer=Midway |publisher=Midway |date=2002-11-20 |level=Reptile biography card}} Reptile pledges his loyalties to her, though eventually realizes she is merely using him and sets out to kill her. Instead of the vampire he finds [[List of Mortal Kombat characters#Onaga|Onaga's]] dragon egg instead,{{cite video game|title=[[Mortal Kombat: Deadly Alliance]] |developer=Midway |publisher=Midway |date=2002-11-20 |level=Reptile ending}} which transforms Reptile into Onaga's [[Avatar (computing)|avatar]], leading to the events of ''[[Mortal Kombat: Deception|Deception]]''{{cite video game|title=[[Mortal Kombat: Armageddon]] |developer=Midway |publisher=Midway |date=2006-10-11 |level=Onaga Kombat Card video}} and ending with his defeat at the game's conclusion.{{cite web|url=http://mkarmageddon.com/charBio.html?charName=shujinko|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071017105805/http://mkarmageddon.com/charBio.html?charName=shujinko|title=Shujinko bio|publisher=[[Midway Games]]|archivedate=October 17, 2007|accessdate=November 16, 2009}} Separated from Onaga as a result, Reptile returns in ''[[Mortal Kombat: Armageddon]]''. In Konquest mode in ''Armageddon'', he appears in the Red Dragon lair commanding Daegon's dragon Caro to close the portal but refused. Taven battles Reptile in combat and emerges victorious. Reptile also appears in ''[[Mortal Kombat: Shaolin Monks]]'', appearing in the game's opening sequence and later as a boss.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051107202543/http://www.gameinformer.com/News/Story/200509/N05.0919.1920.37484.htm |archivedate=2005-11-07 |url= http://www.gameinformer.com/News/Story/200509/N05.0919.1920.37484.htm|date=2005-09-19|title=Mortal Kombat: Shaolin Monks Hands-On Impressions|publisher=''[[Game Informer]]''|author=Vore, Bryan|accessdate=2008-12-26}} During development, producer Shaun Himmerick noted that Reptile was included in the game because the character was one of Himmerick's favorite in the series.{{cite web|url= http://www.mortalkombatonline.com/content/forum/showmessage.cds?id=52997|title=Developer Diary#3: Characters|publisher=Mortal Kombat Online|author=Himmerick, Shaun|accessdate=2008-12-26}} Originally included in ''[[NBA Jam Tournament Edition]]'' alongside other ''Mortal Kombat'' characters as an unlockable player, he was eventually removed from later versions of the game at the request of the [[National Basketball Association|NBA]].{{cite book |author=Staff |title=NBA JAM Tournament Edition Player's Guide|year=1995 |publisher=[[BradyGames]]|isbn=1-56686-232-9}} Reptile reappears in the 2011 ''[[Mortal Kombat (2011 video game)|Mortal Kombat]]'' video game, retelling his role from the first tournaments. In ''[[Mortal Kombat X]]'' (2015), Reptile follows Kotal Kahn and helps bring about Mileena's removal from the throne. ====Gameplay==== As a secret character in the first ''Mortal Kombat'', Reptile features a hybrid of Sub-Zero's and Scorpion's attacks, such as the former's freezing projectile and the latter's harpoon.{{cite book |author=Publications International, Ltd|title=Mortal Kombat Action Strategies: An Authorized Player's Guide|year=1993 |publisher=New Amer Library|isbn=0-451-82290-0}} When made a playable character for later installments, his moves were changed completely. His "Forceball" attack creates an energy ball from his hands, while his "Acid Spit" attack produces a higher, faster projectile. Reptile can slide towards the opponent, or turn invisible for a brief period of time or until hit.{{cite book |author=Taylor, Matt | author2=Fink, Jim|title=Mortal Kombat II: Official Player's Guide|year=1995 |publisher=Infotainment|isbn=1-57280-028-3}} Later titles in the series modify these moves, such as splitting the Forceball attack into slow and fast variants, or remove moves in favor of different attacks, only to return them in the next installment.{{cite book |author=Arnold, Douglas |title=Mortal Kombat 4 Survival Guide: Players Guide|year=1998 |publisher=Semantix Design Llc|isbn=1-884364-44-6}} Reptile's [[Fatality (Mortal Kombat)|Fatalities]] in ''Mortal Kombat II'' consist of revealing his reptilian face in order to devour the opponent's head, or turning invisible and severing the opponent's torso. Later finishing moves expand upon the concept, ranging from [[Regurgitation (digestion)|regurgitating]] acid upon the opponent to leaping upon their body and gnawing the flesh from their skulls. In a series retrospective, the ''Mortal Kombat'' development team named Reptile's finishers as some of their favorites from the series.{{cite video game|title=[[Mortal Kombat: Armageddon]] Premium Edition |developer=Midway |publisher=Midway |date=2006-10-11 |level="The History of Fatalities" commentary}} ===In other media=== [[Image:Reptile-MK-movie.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Keith Cooke]] as Reptile in the film ''[[Mortal Kombat (film)|Mortal Kombat]]'']] Reptile appears as a minor character in several of [[Malibu Comics]]' ''Mortal Kombat'' comic book series released in 1995, debuting in the ''Goro: Prince of Pain'' miniseries as a member of a team led by Kitana to find the missing [[Goro (Mortal Kombat)|Goro]],{{Cite comic | writer = Charles Marshall | inker = Bruce McCorkindale | penciller = Kiki Chansamone | story = Armed and Dangerous | title = [[Mortal Kombat (comics)#Comics published by Malibu|Mortal Kombat - Goro: Prince of Pain]] | issue = 3 | date = 1995 | publisher = [[Malibu Comics]] | location = [[Calabasas, California]]}} later appearing in the ''Battlewave'' miniseries hypnotizing [[Sonya Blade]] into wanting to marry Shao Kahn,Marshall, Charles (1996). ''Mortal Kombat: Battlewave''. [[Norma Editorial]]. {{ISBN|84-7904-360-1}}. and in several [[One-shot (comics)|one-shots]], such as ''Kitana and Mileena''.{{Cite comic | writer = Charles Marshall | inker = Larry Welch| penciller = [[Greg Horn]] | title = [[Mortal Kombat (comics)#Comics published by Malibu|Mortal Kombat - Kitana and Mileena]] | date = 1996 | publisher = [[Malibu Comics]] | location = [[Calabasas, California]]}} He also appears in comics published by Midway for ''Mortal Kombat II'' and ''Mortal Kombat 4'', based on his role in each title.{{Cite comic | writer = Charles Marshall | penciller = Patrick Rolo | inker = Abraham Madison | title = [[Mortal Kombat (comics)#Comics published by Midway|Mortal Kombat Tournament Edition II]] | date = 1993 | publisher = [[Midway Games]]}}{{Cite comic | writer = Charles Marshall | penciller = Patrick Rolo | inker = Abraham Madison | title = [[Mortal Kombat (comics)#Comics published by Midway|Mortal Kombat 4]] | date = 1997 | publisher = [[Midway Games]]}} In the comics, Reptile speaks in the same hissing tone as he does in the games. A paperback novel written by C. Dean Anderson entitled ''Mortal Kombat: Reptile's World'' was released in 1996. Written for junior readers, the book described the past of Reptile's fictional race through the eyes of other series characters.{{cite book |title=Mortal Kombat: Reptile's World |last=Anderson |first=C. Dean |year=1996 |publisher=Berkley Books |isbn=1-57297-131-2 }} Reptile later appears in the 1995 film ''[[Mortal Kombat (film)|Mortal Kombat]]'' as a [[bipedalism|bipedal]] [[lizard]], camouflaging himself until found by [[Liu Kang]]. After being thrown into a statue, Reptile transforms into a human-looking ninja and battles Liu Kang, but is defeated and then crushed after reverting to his original form. Reptile's lizard form was rendered with the use of [[computer-generated imagery]], while the character's human form is portrayed by [[Keith Cooke]], clothed similar to Scorpion and Sub-Zero in the film, but green and with a fanged open mouth imprinted on his face mask.{{cite book |author1=Goldman, Michael |author2=Aaron, Richard E. |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Mortal Kombat: The Movie Behind the Scenes|year=1995 |publisher=[[Prima Games]]|isbn=0-7615-0082-0}} Originally not included in the movie, Reptile was added in response to [[focus groups]] being unimpressed with the original fights in the film.{{cite journal| last = Reed| first = Dr. Craig D.| date = 1998-01-01| title = Mortal Kombat: Annihilation - Behind the Scenes at the New Hollywood Blockbuster| journal = [[Black Belt (magazine)|Black Belt]]| volume= 36| issue= 1| pages = 85| publisher = Active Interest Media, Inc.| issn = 0277-3066}} Actor [[Robin Shou]] (Liu Kang) and director [[Paul W. S. Anderson|Paul Anderson]] noted that neither knew what Reptile's lizard form would look like until after filming, making the pre-fight sequence difficult to shoot.{{cite video |date = 1996-05-21 |title = [[Mortal Kombat: The Journey Begins]] |type = [[VHS]] |publisher = [[Turner Home Entertainment]] |accessdate = 2008-12-26 |location = ''Behind the Scenes'' commentary}} The 1998 television series ''[[Mortal Kombat: Konquest]]'' features Reptile in his human form, portrayed by Jon Valera. Commander of Shao Kahn's Raptors, he betrays Kahn and forms an alliance with Kreeya to share dominion over Kahn's domain and serve as one of her [[mating|mates]], only to be killed later during an ambush by Shao Kahn's priests.{{cite video |date = 2000 |title = [[Mortal Kombat: Conquest]] |type = [[DVD]] |publisher = [[CTVglobemedia]] |location = Australia |accessdate = 2008-12-26}} A similar character named Komodai appears in the animated ''[[Mortal Kombat: Defenders of the Realm#Episode 3: "Acid Tongue"|Mortal Kombat]]'' series' third episode, leading an attack with other Raptors. Voiced by Josh Blyden, he is defeated and sent back to Outworld.{{cite video |date = 2001 |title = [[Mortal Kombat: Defenders of the Realm]] |type = [[DVD]] |publisher = [[Threshold Entertainment]] |accessdate = 2008-12-26}} Reptile featured in director [[Kevin Tancharoen]]'s 2010 short film ''[[Mortal Kombat: Rebirth]]'', a grittier, more realistic take on the ''MK'' canon. He was played by Richard Dorton and depicted therein as a [[human cannibalism|cannibalistic]] [[crime|criminal]] who eats his victims' heads after killing them. While not an inhuman ninja, the character suffers from a real-life [[disease]] known as [[Harlequin-type ichthyosis]], giving him patchy [[Scale (dermatology)|scale]]-like skin and eyes that are grown inward. Reptile was the only character from the film who did not carry over into Tancharoen's ''[[Mortal Kombat: Legacy]]'' web series.{{cite web |url=http://www.1up.com/do/newsStory?cId=3179728 |title=Mortal Kombat Trailer is Director's Pitch for MK Film |author=Pigna, Kris |date=2010-06-09 |accessdate=2010-06-09 |work=[[1UP.com]] |publisher=[[UGO Networks]] }}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite web |url=http://www.craveonline.com/entertainment/film/article/exclusive-interview-with-mortal-kombat-actor-104127 |title=Exclusive Interview with Mortal Kombat Actor |author=Young, Becky |publisher=[[CraveOnline]] |date=2010-06-09 |accessdate=2010-06-10}} [[Skrillex]] released the single "Reptile's Theme", referring to the ''Mortal Kombat'' character and sampling from the game, in a compilation album titled ''[[Mortal Kombat: Songs Inspired by the Warriors]]''. ===Merchandise and promotion=== A Reptile [[action figure]] was released by [[Hasbro]] as part of a [[G.I. Joe]] line of toys, packaged with the series-themed vehicle for the toyline. The figure comes with a katana and grappling hook.{{cite book |author=Santelmo, Vincent |title=The Complete Encyclopedia to GI Joe|year=2001 |page=509|publisher=Krause Publications|isbn=0-87341-874-3}} Another action figure to promote ''Shaolin Monks'' was released in 2006 by Jazwares. Fully posable, it includes an alternate head, detachable tongue and a large-bladed [[scimitar]].{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060819122032/http://www.toywiz.com/reptilemortalkombatseries3actionfigure.html |archivedate=2006-08-19 |url=http://www.toywiz.com/reptilemortalkombatseries3actionfigure.html|title=Mortal Kombat Shaolin Monks Series 3 Action Figure Reptile|publisher=ToyWiz|accessdate=2008-12-26}} He was one of many ''MK'' characters depicted on 2.5" x 3.5" collectible magnets released by Ata-Boy Wholesale in 2011.[http://ataboy.cameoez.com/images/import/29989MK.jpg Reptile 2.5" x 3.5" magnet] - Ata-Boy Wholesale, 2011. Retrieved February 26, 2014. Reptile also featured prominently in the introduction sequence of ''Mortal Kombat 4'', portions of which were used in a television commercial to promote the game.{{cite video game|title=[[Mortal Kombat 4]] |developer=Midway |publisher=Midway |date=1997-10-15 |level=Opening sequence}} ==Reception== The character has been well received by critics. [[GameSpot]] said that Reptile gives the series "an air of mystery" due to the circumstances behind his first appearance,{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/news/6197586.html |title=Midway executes full Mortal Kombat vs. DC roster |publisher=[[GameSpot]] |author=Sinclair, Brendan |date=2008-09-11 |accessdate=2008-12-25 }}{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} while [[CraveOnline]] listed the battle against him in ''Mortal Kombat'' as the fourth greatest event in video gaming.{{cite web|url=http://www.craveonline.com/articles/gaming/04649410/4/top_10_most_pantscrappingly_awesome_video_game_secrets.html|title=Top 10 Most Pants-Crappingly Awesome Video Game Secrets|publisher=Craveonline|author=Azevedo, Jeremy|date=2008-01-13|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080202132441/http://www.craveonline.com/articles/gaming/04649410/4/top_10_most_pantscrappingly_awesome_video_game_secrets.html|archivedate=2008-02-02|accessdate=2008-12-25}} [[UGO.com]] ranked him eleventh in their list of top ''Mortal Kombat'' characters, stating that his exclusivity as a hidden character in the original game made him an "arcade legend" and set the tone for secrets in future titles in the series, and adding, "future games would feature even more hidden enemies and complicated ways of accessing them, but the first was still the best."{{cite web|url=http://www.ugo.com/games/mortal-kombat-characters|title=Reptile - Top 11 Mortal Kombat Characters|publisher=[[UGO.com]]|author=Schedeen, Jesse|accessdate=2008-12-23|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120729020022/http://www.ugo.com/games/mortal-kombat-characters|archivedate=2012-07-29|df=}} He was also fifth in [[Game Revolution]]'s list of top "old school" ''Mortal Kombat'' characters", praised for his introduction in ''Mortal Kombat'' and his changes in the sequel.{{cite web|first=K. Thor|last=Jensen|date=2011-02-03|title=Top 10 Old School Mortal Kombat Characters|url=http://www.gamerevolution.com/features/top-10-old-school-mortal-kombat-characters/2|author2=Severino, Anthony|publisher=Game Revolution|accessdate=2011-05-23}} [[IGN]] listed him as a character they would like to see as [[downloadable content]] for ''[[Mortal Kombat vs. DC Universe]]'', noting "It's just not (a ''Mortal Kombat'') game without a bevy of palette-swapped ninjas...and our vote goes to Reptile," adding that while the character would be a "pain in the ass to fight sometimes", his inclusion would be "a blessing to have on your side."{{cite web|url=http://stars.ign.com/articles/909/909852p10.html|title=DLC Player Wanted MK vs. DC|publisher=[[IGN]]|author=Schedeen, Jesse|date=2008-09-12|accessdate=2008-12-24}} He was also featured in the 2008 [[MSN]] article about the ten greatest Easter eggs in gaming.{{cite web|url=http://tech.uk.msn.com/features/article.aspx?cp-documentid=7848251 |title=10 greatest gaming Easter eggs |publisher=[[MSN]] |author=Taylor, Nik |accessdate=2009-11-05 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080327200528/http://tech.uk.msn.com/features/article.aspx?cp-documentid=7848251 |archivedate=2008-03-27 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In 2010 UGO, included him on the list of the 25 coolest hidden characters in video gaming.{{cite web|url=http://www.ugo.com/games/reptile |title=The 25 Awesomest Hidden Characters |publisher=[[UGO.com]] |accessdate=2010-12-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101209064450/http://www.ugo.com/games/reptile |archivedate=2010-12-09 |df= }} [[ScrewAttack]] placed Reptile at ninth place on their list of [[ScrewAttack's Top 10|top ten ''Mortal Kombat'' characters]], commenting that anyone who got to fight him in the original ''Mortal Kombat'' became a local legend and getting to play as him and turn invisible in ''Mortal Kombat II'' was "icing on the cake".{{cite web|url=http://www.screwattack.com/shows/originals/screwattack-top-10s/top-10-mortal-kombat-kharacters |title=Top 10 Mortal Kombat Kharacters |series=''[[ScrewAttack's Top 10]]'' |publisher=ScrewAttack.com |date= |accessdate=2011-10-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111213182751/http://www.screwattack.com/shows/originals/screwattack-top-10s/top-10-mortal-kombat-kharacters |archivedate=2011-12-13 |df= }} In [[UGO Networks]]' 2012 list of the top ''Mortal Kombat'' characters, Reptile placed as sixth, stating that he is the best hidden character in the series.{{cite web|author=UGO Team |url=http://www.ugo.com/games/mortal-kombat-characters?page=5 |title=Top 50 Mortal Kombat Characters - Mortal Kombat |publisher=UGO.com |date=2012-02-28 |accessdate=2012-03-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120929141958/http://www.ugo.com/games/mortal-kombat-characters?page=5 |archivedate=2012-09-29 |df= }} Cheat Code Central included him in the 2012 list of top ten hidden characters in fighting games at number two.Angelo M. D'Argenio, [http://www.cheatcc.com/extra/thetoptenhiddencharactersinfightinggames.html Top Ten Hidden Characters In Fighting Games], Cheat Code Central, February 22, 2012 ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category inline}} {{Mortal Kombat Characters}} {{good article}} [[Category:Action film characters]] [[Category:Avatar characters in video games]] [[Category:Characters created by John Tobias]] [[Category:Extraterrestrial characters in video games]] [[Category:Fictional characters from parallel universes]] [[Category:Fictional cannibals]] [[Category:Fictional henchmen in video games]] [[Category:Fictional Hung Ga practitioners]] [[Category:Fictional Pào Chuí practitioners]] [[Category:Fictional reptilians]] [[Category:Fictional Shaolin kung fu practitioners]] [[Category:Male characters in video games]] [[Category:Mortal Kombat characters]] [[Category:Ninja characters in video games]] [[Category:Shapeshifter characters in video games]] [[Category:Video game antagonists]] [[Category:Video game bosses]] [[Category:Video game characters in comics]] [[Category:Video game characters in film]] [[Category:Video game characters in literature]] [[Category:Video game characters in television]] [[Category:Video game characters introduced in 1992]] [[Category:Video game characters who can turn invisible]] [[Category:Video game secret characters]]

{{Infobox person | name = Ricardo Fort | image = 2009_Ricardo_Fort.jpg | alt = | caption = Ricardo Fort in 2009. | birth_name = Ricardo Aníbal Fort Campa | birth_date = {{Birth date|1968|11|5|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2013|11|25|1968|11|5|df=yes}} | death_place = Buenos Aires, Argentina | nationality = [[Argentine people|Argentine]] | height = {{height|m=1.83}} | other_names = ''Ricky''
''Comandante'' (Commander) | known_for = | occupation = [[Entrepreneur]], [[television director]] |years_active = 2008–2012 |partner = Violeta Lo Re (2009)
Virginia Gallardo (2009–2010)
Erika Mitdank (2010)
[[Claudia Ciardone]] (2010–2012)
|children = 2}} '''Ricardo Aníbal Fort Campa''' (5 November 1968 − 25 November 2013{{cite web |url = http://www.buenosairesherald.com/article/145997/eccentric-actor-businessman-ricardo-fort-dies-at-45 |title = Eccentric actor, businessman Ricardo Fort dies at 45 |date = 25 November 2013 |work = Buenos Aires Herald |accessdate = 25 November 2013}}) was an [[Argentine people|Argentine]] [[socialite]], [[entrepreneur]] and [[television director]]. Although his career lasted only four years, Fort was one of the most popular personalities in his country.{{Cite web|url=http://www.infobae.com/2015/12/15/1776308-los-10-hombres-mas-influyentes-la-argentina-el-2015/|title=Ricardo Fort influential personality 2009 - 20013.|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} ==Early life== The ''Felfort'' [[confectionery]] company was founded in 1912 in Buenos Aires by Fort's grandfather, Felipe Fort, and soon became one of the top confectionery companies in Argentina. Ricardo's father, Carlos Augusto Fort, took control of the company after Felipe's death in 1969. Ricardo Fort developed a close relationship with his mother, the opera singer Marta Campa.[http://personajes.lanacion.com.ar/1642156-marta-fort-rompio-el-silencio-he-perdido-lo-mas-importante-de-mi-vida Marta Fort rompió el silencio: "He perdido lo más hermoso de mi vida" BASTA CHICOS], ''[[La Nación]]'', 25 November 2013 {{es}} == Businesses == Fort developed businesses in the [[textile]] industry and in modeling, as well as owned the ''Fortmen'' clothing line.{{cite web |url=http://www.aquishow.com.ar/espectaculos/Ricardo_Fort_presento_su_fragancia_masculina-Fortmen/6022 |title=Ricardo Fort presentó su fragancia masculina "Fortmen" | Espectáculos |publisher=Aquishow |date= |accessdate=29 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120321171135/http://www.aquishow.com.ar/espectaculos/Ricardo_Fort_presento_su_fragancia_masculina-Fortmen/6022 |archivedate=21 March 2012 |df= }} ==Theater== {| class="wikitable" |- !Year !Production |- |2010 |''Fortuna'' |- |2011 |''Fortuna 2'' |- |2012 |''Mi novio, mi novia y yo'' |- |2013 |''Fort con caviar'' |} ==Television== In 2009, Fort participated in the reality series ''El musical de tus sueños''.{{citation needed|date=September 2012}} In 2010, Fort was selected to be one of the judges of the seventh season of ''Bailando por un Sueño 2010''.{{citation needed|date=September 2012}} In 2011 he worked in the theatrical production ''Fortuna 2''.{{cite web |url=http://exitoina.com/ensayo-de-fortuna-2-el-musical-de-ricardo-fort/ |title=Ensayo de "Fortuna 2", el musical de Ricardo Fort |publisher=Exitoina |date=4 January 2011 |accessdate=29 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110710211626/http://exitoina.com/ensayo-de-fortuna-2-el-musical-de-ricardo-fort/ |archivedate=10 July 2011 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.ciudad.com.ar/tags/fortuna-2 |title=Fortuna 2 |publisher=Ciudad.com |date= |accessdate=29 May 2012}} {| class="wikitable" |- !Year !Program !Channel !Role |- |2009 | ''El musical de tus sueños'' | Canal Trece |Himself |- |2009 | Showmatch, ''El musical de tus sueños'' | Canal Trece | Participant |- |2010 | Showmatch, ''Bailando por un sueño'' 2010 | Canal Trece | Judge |- |2012 | ''Fort Night Show'' | América TV | Conductor |} ==Music== Fort released a single called ''No volverás'' early in his career. ==Personal life== In 2010, Fort revealed in an interview on the talk show ''Tienen la Palabra'' that his twin children Felipe and Marta were born of a [[surrogate pregnancy|surrogate]] mother found through the auspices of a company in [[California]]. He was openly [[bisexual]].{{cite web |url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1389553-fort-me-he-acostado-con-hombres-cuando-era-joven |title=Fort: "Me acosté con hombres cuando era joven" |date=15 July 2011 | accessdate=1 November 2012}} ==Death== Fort died on 25 November 2013 in a Buenos Aires clinic, due to cardiac arrest following a [[gastrointestinal bleeding]]. He was being treated for a knee injury he suffered a few months before. He was 45 years old. Just days before, he had also suffered a [[femoral fracture]] in [[Miami]], [[Florida]].[http://www.clarin.com/espectaculos/personajes/Hablo-cunanda-Fort-hemorragia-interna_0_1036096663.html Habló la cuñada de Fort: "La causa de la muerte fue una hemorragia digestiva"] ''Clarín'', 25 November 2013 {{es icon}} == References == {{cite web | url=http://www.diarioshow.com/notas/2009/11/26/22799-felfort-el-imperio-de-ricardo-fort.html | title=Felfort, El Imperio de Ricardo Fort (Spanish) | accessdate=17 March 2011 | date=26 November 2009 | work=diarioshow.com | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110428185544/http://www.diarioshow.com/notas/2009/11/26/22799-felfort-el-imperio-de-ricardo-fort.html | archivedate=28 April 2011 | df= }} {{cite news | url=http://www.diaadia.com.ar/?q=content/ricardo-fort-mis-hijos-son-los-mas-felices-del-mundo-0 | title=Ricardo Fort: Mis hijos son los más felices del mundo (Spanish) | accessdate=17 March 2011 | date=8 December 2009 | work=Dia a Dia}} ==External links== {{Commonscat}} *{{IMDb name|4662591}} *{{findagrave|120790935}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Fort, Ricardo}} [[Category:1968 births]] [[Category:2013 deaths]] [[Category:Argentine television personalities]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Buenos Aires]] [[Category:LGBT people from Argentina]] [[Category:Argentine male stage actors]] [[Category:Argentine male television actors]] [[Category:Bisexual male actors]] [[Category:Deaths from bleeding]] [[Category:Argentine socialites]] [[Category:Argentine businesspeople]]

[[File:US Navy 040609-N-5471P-013 Symbolic of a fallen leader who will never ride again, the Caparisoned horse is led down Constitution Ave., following the Caisson carrying the body of former U.S. President Ronald Reagan.jpg|thumb|300px|right|The riderless horse named [[Sergeant York (horse)|Sergeant York]], during the [[funeral procession]] for the 40th President of the United States, [[Ronald Reagan]], with President Reagan's boots reversed in the stirrups.]] A '''riderless horse''' (which may be [[caparison]]ed in ornamental and protective coverings, having a detailed protocol of their own) is a single horse, without a rider, and with boots reversed in the stirrups, which sometimes accompanies a [[funeral]] procession. The horse follows the [[Caisson (vehicle)|caisson]] carrying the [[coffin|casket]].<ref name="USDofD"> {{cite web | url = http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=26292 | title = Customs of Military Funerals Reflect History, Tradition|work= United States Department of Defence American Forces Press Service | accessdate = 28 April 2010 }}</ref> A riderless horse can also be featured in military parades to symbolize fallen soldiers. In Australia for example, it is traditional for a riderless horse known as the 'Lone Charger' to lead the annual [[Anzac Day]] marches.<ref name="AustWarMem"> {{cite web | url = http://www.awm.gov.au/commemoration/customs/charger.asp | title = The lone charger|work= Australian War Memorial | accessdate = 4 December 2012 }}</ref>
==History== [[File:Jousting horse, funeral procession of Archduke Albert VII of Austria.jpeg|thumb|Riderless [[jousting]] horse of [[Albert VII, Archduke of Austria]] in his funeral procession, 1623 (etching with hand coloring by [[Jacob Franquart]])]] The custom is believed to date back to the time of [[Genghis Khan]], when a horse was sacrificed to serve the fallen warrior in the next world. The riderless horse later came to symbolize a warrior who would ride no more.<ref name="cnn-riderless">{{cite news| url = http://www.cnn.com/2008/LIVING/05/23/arlington.riderless.horse/| title = Riderless horse adds poignancy to military burials| work = CNN.com| accessdate = 30 March 2014| date=May 23, 2008}}</ref>
In the [[United States]], the riderless horse is part of the military honors given to an [[United States Army|Army]] or [[United States Marine Corps|Marine Corps]] officer who was a [[Colonel (United States)|colonel]] or above; this includes the [[President of the United States|President]], by virtue of having been the country's commander in chief and the [[United States Secretary of Defense|Secretary of Defense]], having overseen the armed forces. [[Alexander Hamilton]], former Secretary of the Treasury (1789-1795) was the first American to be given the honor. Historian Ron Chernow noted that Hamilton's gray horse followed the casket "with the boots and spurs of its former rider reversed in the stirrups."<ref name=Chernow>{{cite book|last1=Chernow|first1=Ron|title=Alexander Hamilton|date=2004|publisher=Penguin Press|location=New York|isbn=978-1-59420-009-0|pages= 710–712}}</ref> [[Abraham Lincoln]] was the first president of the United States to be officially honored by the inclusion of the riderless horse in his funeral cortege,<ref name="USDofD" /> although a letter from [[George Washington's]] personal secretary recorded the president's horse was part of the president's funeral, carrying his saddle, pistols, and holsters.<ref name="WHH"> {{cite web |url = http://www.whitehousehistory.org/whha_publications/publications_documents/whitehousehistory_19.pdf |title = Arlington’s Ceremonial Horses and Funerals at the White House |work = White House History.org |accessdate = 28 April 2010 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100626081049/http://www.whitehousehistory.org/whha_publications/publications_documents/whitehousehistory_19.pdf |archivedate = 26 June 2010 |df = }}</ref> Traditionally, simple black riding boots are reversed in the stirrups to represent a fallen commander looking back on his troops for the last time.
==Notable horses==
=== Old Bob === In 1865, Abraham Lincoln was honored by the inclusion of a riderless horse at his funeral. When Lincoln's funeral train reached [[Springfield, Illinois]], his horse, [[Old Bob]], who was draped in a black mourning blanket, followed the procession and led mourners to Lincoln's burial spot.<ref name="bj-america"> {{cite book | title = Black Jack: America's famous riderless horse | last = Knuckle | first = Robert | authorlink = | year = 2002 | publisher = General Store Publishing House | url = https://books.google.com/?id=jiQwfCOryiMC&dq=riderless+horse+Old+Bob | location = | isbn = 9781894263658 | page = 4 }}</ref>
=== Black Jack ===
[[File:JFKcapitolNov25'63.jpg|thumb|right|[[Black Jack (horse)|Black Jack]] in John F. Kennedy's funeral procession]]
A notable riderless horse was "[[Black Jack (horse)|Black Jack]]," a half-[[Morgan horse|Morgan]] named for [[General of the Armies]] [[John Pershing|John "Black Jack" Pershing]]. Black Jack took part in the state funerals of Presidents [[John F. Kennedy]] (1963),<ref> {{cite web | url = http://www.history.army.mil/books/Last_Salute/ch23.htm | title = The Last Salute: Civil and Military Funeral, 1921–1969 – Chapter 23 – The Last Salute | work = history.army.mil | date = 24 May 2005 | accessdate = 28 April 2010 }}</ref> [[Herbert Hoover]] (1964), and [[Lyndon Johnson]] (1973), and General of the Army [[Douglas MacArthur]] (1964).<ref name="army-caisson"> {{cite web |url = http://www.army.mil/info/organization/unitsandcommands/commandstructure/theoldguard/specplt/caisson.htm |title = The Old Guard — Caisson Platoon |work = Army.mil |accessdate = 2010-04-28 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100228155422/http://www.army.mil/info/organization/unitsandcommands/commandstructure/theoldguard/specplt/caisson.htm |archivedate = 2010-02-28 |df = }}</ref><ref>Barakat, Matthew, "Riderless horse will symbolize the nation's mourning", ''[[Daily Breeze]]'', Torrance, California, June 9, 2004. pg. A.10.</ref>
Black Jack was foaled January 19, 1947, and came to [[Fort Myer]] from [[Fort Reno, Oklahoma]], on November 22, 1952. Black Jack was the last of the [[United States Army Quartermaster Corps|Quartermaster]]-issue horses branded with the Army's U.S. brand (on the left shoulder) and his Army serial number 2V56 (on the left side of his neck). He died on February 6, 1976, and was buried on the parade ground of Fort Myer's Summerall Field with full military honors, one of only two US Army horses to be given that honor.<ref>Belcher, Nancy Hoyt, "Arlington Cemetery, Fort Myer pay homage to the military", ''[[The Record (Bergen County)|The Record]]'', Bergen County, N.J.: April 6, 2003. pg. T.03.</ref>
=== Dolly ===
"Dolly", was the 22 year old charger (whose official name was Octave) of [[Admiral of the Fleet]] [[Louis Mountbatten, 1st Earl Mountbatten of Burma|The Earl Mountbatten of Burma]] in his capacity as [[Colonel_(United_Kingdom)#Ceremonial_usage|Colonel]] of the [[Life Guards (United Kingdom)|Life Guards]]. Following the assassination of Lord Mountbatten by the [[Provisional Irish Republican Army|IRA]] in [[Mullaghmore, County Sligo|Mullaghmore]], Dolly served as the riderless horse in the funeral procession being led ahead the head of the gun carriage with the Lord Mountbatten's boots (from his Colonel's uniform) reversed in the stirrups on 5 September 1979.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/september/5/newsid_2499000/2499279.stm 1979: Mountbatten buried after final parade]</ref>
=== Sergeant York ===
"[[Sergeant York (horse)|Sergeant York]]" was formerly known as "Allaboard Jules", a racing [[standardbred]] gelding. He was renamed (in honor of famous WWI soldier [[Alvin C. York]]) when he was accepted into the military in 1997. He served as the riderless horse in [[Death and state funeral of Ronald Reagan|President Ronald Reagan's funeral procession]], walking behind the caisson bearing Reagan's flag-draped casket. In the stirrups were President Reagan's personal riding boots.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2004-06-08/news/18255369_1_horse-standardbred-dead-lame | location=New York | work=Daily News | title=Sgt. York's Solemn Trek}}</ref>
He was foaled in 1991, sired by Royce and out of the mare Amtrak Collins sired by Computer. He is a descendant of the great [[standardbred]] racing stallions Albatross, Tar Heel and Adios.
== See also == *[[Honor guard]] *[[Military funeral]] *[[Military rites]] * [[Missing man formation]] *[[State funeral]]

{{Infobox Congressman | name = Timothy Childs | image name = | state1 = [[New York (state)|New York]] | district1 = [[New York's 28th congressional district|28th]] | term_start1 = March 4, 1841 | term_end1 = March 3, 1843 | preceded1 = [[Thomas Kempshall]] | succeeded1 = [[Thomas J. Paterson]] | term_start2 = March 4, 1835 | term_end2 = March 3, 1839 | preceded2 = [[Frederick Whittlesey]] | succeeded2 = [[Thomas Kempshall]] | office3 = [[United States House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform|Chairman of the Committee on Expenditures in the Post Office Department]] | term3 = 1837-1839 | office4 = Member of the [[New York State Assembly]] | term4 = 1833 | state5 = [[New York (state)|New York]] | district5 = [[New York's 27th congressional district|27th]] | term_start5 = March 4, 1829 | term_end5 = March 3, 1831 | preceded5 = [[Daniel D. Barnard]] | succeeded5 = [[Frederick Whittlesey]] | office6 = Member of the [[New York State Assembly]] | term6 = 1828 | office7 = [[Monroe County, New York|Monroe County]] [[District attorney]] | term7 = 1821-1831 | birth_date = {{birth date|1790|01|01}} | birth_place = [[Pittsfield, Massachusetts]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1847|11|08|1790|01|01}} | death_place = At sea aboard the ship ''Emily'' | spouse = Catherine Adams
Louisa S. Dickinson | profession = lawyer | party = [[Federalist Party|Federalist]]
[[Anti-Masonic Party|Anti-Masonic]]
[[National Republican Party|Anti-Jacksonian]]
[[Whig Party (United States)|Whig]] | alma_mater = [[Williams College]]
[[Litchfield Law School]] |}} [[File:Timothy Childs Jr Death record 2.jpg|thumb|right|125px|Death record, Timothy Childs, Jr.]] [[File:Timothy Childs, Jr. Obit.jpg|thumb|right|125px|Obituary for Timothy Childs, Jr. Oneida (N.Y.) Morning Herald, December 8, 1847]] '''Timothy Childs Jr.''' (January 1, 1790 – November 8, 1847) was a [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] from [[New York (state)|New York]]. ==Early life== Childs was born in [[Pittsfield, Massachusetts]] on January 1, 1790.Massachusetts Town and Vital Records, 1620-1988, birth entry for Timothy Childs, retrieved via Ancestry.com, October 4, 2013 He was the son of Rachel ([[née]] Easton) Childs (1760–1852) and Timothy Childs (1748–1821), a [[American Revolutionary War|Revolutionary War]] officer who studied at [[Harvard]], became a physician and served in the [[Massachusetts House of Representatives]]. He graduated from [[Williams College]] in 1811William Thomas Davis, [https://books.google.com/books?id=GqAsAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA291 Bench and Bar of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts], Volume 2, 1895, page 291 and [[Litchfield Law School]] in 1814.Marian C. McKenna, [https://books.google.com/books?id=tfqwAAAAIAAJ&q=%22timothy+childs%22+%22litchfield+law+school%22&dq=%22timothy+childs%22+%22litchfield+law+school%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=irdOUrnzKZjd4APd04HYBg&ved=0CEYQ6AEwAA Tapping Reeve and the Litchfield Law School], 1986, page 189 He completed his studies at the [[Albany, New York|Albany]] firm of [[Harmanus Bleecker]],{{cite news |title= From Saint Croix |work=Oneida (N.Y.) Morning Herald |date=December 8, 1847 |url=http://fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2020/Utica%20NY%20Morning%20Herald/Utica%20NY%20Oneida%20Morning%20Herald%201847-1848/Utica%20NY%20Oneida%20Morning%20Herald%201847-1848%20-%200127.pdf}} afterwards practicing law in [[New York (state)|New York]], first in [[Canandaigua (city), New York|Canandaigua]], and then in [[Rochester, New York|Rochester]].Blake McKelvey, [https://books.google.com/books?id=GJD6xfqgzxAC&pg=PA21 Rochester on the Genessee: The Growth of a City], 1993, page 21 ==Career== Originally a [[Federalist Party|Federalist]],Rochester Historical Society, [https://books.google.com/books?ei=ggxPUrX6ApTU9ATa8YGYCw&id=1TALAQAAMAAJ&dq=%22timothy+childs%22+whig&q=federalist#search_anchor Publications], Volume 21, 1943, page 63 while residing in Canandaigua, Childs served in offices including [[Ontario County, New York|Ontario County]] Commissioner and the judicial position of Master in Chancery.[https://books.google.com/books?id=0EOAU7GAh-AC&pg=PA19 Index to the Newspapers Published in Geneva, New York], Volume 1, 1981, page 19 He served as [[Monroe County, New York]] [[District Attorney]] from 1821 to 1831, the first to hold this position.William Farley Peck, [https://books.google.com/books?id=6tUwAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA369 Semi-Centennial History of the City of Rochester], 1884, page 369William Farley Peck, [https://books.google.com/books?id=IvssAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA358 History of Rochester and Monroe County, New York], Volume 1, 1908, page 358 He served as a member of the [[New York State Assembly]] in 1828,W. H. McIntosh, [https://books.google.com/books?id=pY06AQAAIAAJ&pg=PA39 History of Monroe County, New York], 1877, page 39 and in the late 1820s he also served as Monroe County Judge.Rochester Daily Advertiser and Telegram, [http://fultonhistory.com/Newspaper4/Rochester%20NY%20Daily%20Advertiser%20&%20Telegram/Rochester%20NY%20Daily%20Advertiser%20&%20Telegram%201829%20Grayscale.pdf/Rochester%20NY%20Daily%20Advertiser%20&%20Telegram%201829%20Grayscale%20-%200746.pdf Legal Notices], April, 1829Batavia Republican Advocate, [http://fultonhistory.com/newspaper%2011/Batavia%20%20NY%20Republican%20Advocate/Batavia%20NY%20Republican%20Advocate%201829-1833%20Grayscale/Batavia%20NY%20Republican%20Advocate%201829-1833%20Grayscale%20-%200485.pdf Legal Notices], April, 1829National Youth Administration, [http://www.libraryweb.org/~digitized/newsindex/1818-1850/CAD-COU.pdf Index to Newspapers Published in Rochester, New York, 1818-1897], digitized 2006, page 271 Childs was elected as an [[Anti-Masonic Party|Anti-Mason]] to the [[21st United States Congress|Twenty-first]] Congress (March 4, 1829 – March 3, 1831).E. and G. W. Blunt, [https://books.google.com/books?id=YLUTAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA473 The American Annual Register for the Year 1829-30], 1832, page 473Sherry Penney, [https://books.google.com/books?id=dh0dAAAAMAAJ&q=%22timothy+childs%22+%22anti-mason%22&dq=%22timothy+childs%22+%22anti-mason%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=dLxOUpaZK7Dc4AOOoYCADQ&ved=0CFEQ6AEwBg Patrician in Politics: Daniel Dewey Barnard of New York], 1974, page 17 After his term expired he returned to practicing law in Rochester. In 1833, he was elected again to the New York State Assembly.Edwin Williams, editor, [https://books.google.com/books?id=pxYXAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA278 Williams's New York Annual Register], 1833, page 278 In 1834, he was elected as an [[National Republican Party|Anti-Jacksonian]] to the [[24th United States Congress|Twenty-fourth]] Congress.Niles' Weekly Register, [https://books.google.com/books?id=VuUMAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA166 Elections], Volume 47, November 15, 1834, page 166 He was reelected as a [[Whig Party (United States)|Whig]] in 1836,Niles' Weekly Register, [https://books.google.com/books?ei=Z71OUt2lD_Wr4APN8YGwDA&id=YPAaAAAAYAAJ&dq=%22timothy+childs%22+whig+1836&q=%22timothy+childs%22#search_anchor Elections], Volume 51, December 10, 1836, page 177 and served from March 4, 1835 to March 3, 1839. During his 1837 to 1839 term Childs was appointed Chairman of the Committee on Expenditures in the Post Office Department.Perry M. Goldman, James S. Young, editors, [https://books.google.com/books?id=DH8nw7pzZrcC&pg=PA337 The United States Congressional Directories, 1789-1840], 1973, page 337 Childs was elected to Congress again as a [[Whig Party (United States)|Whig]] in 1840 and served one term, March 4, 1841 to March 3, 1843.Niles' Weekly Register, [https://books.google.com/books?id=v7IRAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA179 Elections], Volume 59, November 21, 1840, page 170 He resumed practicing law following the completion of his final term in Congress. ==Death and burial== In the late 1840s, Childs traveled to [[Saint Croix, U.S. Virgin Islands|Saint Croix]], where he went in an effort to improve his health.Judy J. Stebbins, Painesville Telegram microfilm transcript, [http://www.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~ohlake/newspaper/PainesvilleTelegraphNoticesMin1830-1861JudyStebbins.pdf Dec. 8, 1847 Wed.], May 8, 2012, pages 203 (two entries)Watertown Chronicle, Death notice, Hon. Timothy Childs, December 22, 1847 He died aboard the ship ''Emily'' on November 25, 1847 while en route from Saint Croix to the United States.Oneida Morning Herald, [http://fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2020/Utica%20NY%20Morning%20Herald/Utica%20NY%20Oneida%20Morning%20Herald%201847-1848/Utica%20NY%20Oneida%20Morning%20Herald%201847-1848%20-%200127.pdf From Saint Croix], December 8, 1847Chapin Family Association, [http://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=mdp.39015071169299;view=1up;seq=211 The Chapin Book of Genealogical Data: With Brief Biographical Sketches of the Descendants of Deacon Samuel Chapin], Volume 1, 1924, page 179Massachusetts Town and Vital Records, 1620-1988, death entry for Timothy Childs, Esq., 1848, retrieved via Ancestry.com, October 4, 2013Geneva Courier, [http://news2.nnyln.net/geneva-ny/geneva-courier/geneva-courier-1842-1847/geneva-courier-1842-1847%20-%200789.pdf A Telegraphic Despatch] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004215736/http://news2.nnyln.net/geneva-ny/geneva-courier/geneva-courier-1842-1847/geneva-courier-1842-1847%20-%200789.pdf |date=2013-10-04 }}, December 8, 1847Batavia Republican Advocate, [http://fultonhistory.com/newspaper%2011/Batavia%20%20NY%20Republican%20Advocate/Batavia%20NY%20Republican%20Advocate%201829-1833%20Grayscale/Batavia%20NY%20Republican%20Advocate%201829-1833%20Grayscale%20-%200485.pdf Legal Notices], April, 1829National Youth Administration, [http://www.libraryweb.org/~digitized/newsindex/1818-1850/CAD-COU.pdf Index to Newspapers Published in Rochester, New York, 1818-1897], digitized 2006, page 274Note: Some sources indicate that Childs died in Santa Cruz, New Mexico. This seems unlikely, given the newspaper references to his travel to the West Indies and his death aboard ship. Vera Cruz, Mexico is also unlikely, given that the Mexican-American War was happening at the time of Childs's death, meaning he wouldn't have gone there to restore his health. Childs was buried in Pittsfield Cemetery in Pittsfield, Massachusetts.{{Findagrave|118548599}} ==Personal life== In 1817, he married Catherine Adams.Hobart and William Smith Colleges, [https://library.hws.edu/archives/newspapers/gni.cfm?index=c Geneva Newspaper Index] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131005002607/https://library.hws.edu/archives/newspapers/gni.cfm?index=c |date=2013-10-05 }}, entry Childs, Timothy, April 9, 1817, retrieved October 4, 2013Some Finger Lakes NY Genealogy, [http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~darmi/Marriages1817.html Transcript of Marriages for 1817], retrieved October 4, 2013 In December, 1830 he married Louisa Stewart ([[née]] Shepherd) Dickinson of [[North Carolina]] in a ceremony in [[Norfolk, Virginia]].George Hobart Tucker, [https://books.google.com/books?id=cDAacwmaVZIC&pg=PA122&lpg=PA122 Abstracts from Norfolk City Marriage Bonds 1797-1850], 1934, page 122Norfolk County, Virginia Genealogy Trails, [http://genealogytrails.com/vir/norfolk/marr_miscellaneous.html Miscellaneous Marriages] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20131004155524/http://genealogytrails.com/vir/norfolk/marr_miscellaneous.html |date=2013-10-04 }}, published in the National Intelligencer, January 1, 1831 Louisa was the widow of Joel Dickinson.Charles Poytnz Stewart, [https://books.google.com/books?id=IS0BAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA148 Historic Memorials of the Stewarts of Forthergill, Perthshire, and their Male Descendants], 1879, page 148 ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{CongBio|C000355}} *[http://www.litchfieldhistoricalsociety.org/ledger/students/599 Timothy Childs, Jr.], Litchfield Historical Society, The Ledger: A Database of Students of the Litchfield Law School and the Litchfield Female Academy * {{fg|118548599}} {{s-start}} {{s-par|us-hs}} {{USRepSuccessionBox | state= New York | district= 27 | before= [[Daniel D. Barnard]] | after= [[Frederick Whittlesey]] | years= 1829–1831}} {{USRepSuccessionBox | state= New York | district= 28 | before= [[Frederick Whittlesey]] | after= [[Thomas Kempshall]] | years= 1835–1839}} {{USRepSuccessionBox | state= New York | district= 28 | before= [[Thomas Kempshall]] | after= [[Thomas J. Paterson]] | years= 1841–1843}} {{s-end}} {{Bioguide}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Childs, Timothy}} [[Category:1790 births]] [[Category:1847 deaths]] [[Category:Politicians from Pittsfield, Massachusetts]] [[Category:New York (state) Federalists]] [[Category:Anti-Masonic Party members of the United States House of Representatives from New York (state)]] [[Category:New York (state) National Republicans]] [[Category:National Republican Party members of the United States House of Representatives]] [[Category:New York (state) Whigs]] [[Category:Whig Party members of the United States House of Representatives]] [[Category:19th-century American politicians]] [[Category:Members of the United States House of Representatives from New York (state)]] [[Category:Members of the New York State Assembly]] [[Category:New York (state) state court judges]] [[Category:New York (state) lawyers]] [[Category:Politicians from Rochester, New York]] [[Category:Williams College alumni]] [[Category:Litchfield Law School alumni]] [[Category:People who died at sea]] [[Category:Anti-Masonic Party politicians from New York (state)]] [[Category:Lawyers from Rochester, New York]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox eruption | name = Toba catastrophe theory | photo = Image:Tobaeruption.png | photo-size = | caption = Artist's impression of the eruption from about {{convert|42|km|mi}} above [[Sumatra|Northern Sumatra]] | date = 74,100—75,900 years ago | volcano = [[Lake Toba|Toba supervolcano]] | type = | location = [[Sumatra]], [[Indonesia]] | coordinates = {{Coord|2.6845|98.8756|region:ID_type:waterbody_scale:500000|display=inline,title}} | VEI = 8 | map = File:Toba zoom.jpg | location-map = | map-size = | map-caption = [[Lake Toba]] is the resulting [[crater lake]]. | impact = Second-most recent [[Supervolcano#Known supereruptions|supereruption]]; impact disputed }}
The '''Toba supereruption''' was a [[Supervolcano|supervolcanic]] [[types of volcanic eruptions|eruption]] that occurred about 75,000 years ago at the site of present-day [[Lake Toba]] in [[Sumatra]], [[Indonesia]]. It is one of the [[Earth]]'s [[List of largest volcanic eruptions|largest known eruptions]]. The '''Toba catastrophe theory''' holds that this event caused a global [[volcanic winter]] of six to ten years and possibly a 1,000-year-long cooling episode.
In 1993, science journalist Ann Gibbons posited that a [[population bottleneck]] occurred in human evolution about 70,000 years ago, and she suggested that this was caused by the eruption. Geologist [[Michael R. Rampino]] of [[New York University]] and volcanologist Stephen Self of the [[University of Hawaii at Manoa]] support her suggestion. In 1998, the bottleneck theory was further developed by anthropologist Stanley H. Ambrose of the [[University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign]]. Both the link and global winter theories are highly controversial.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-22355515 |title=Toba super-volcano catastrophe idea 'dismissed' |website=Bbc.com |date= |accessdate=2017-01-08}} *{{cite web|last=Choi |first=Charles Q. |url=http://www.livescience.com/29130-toba-supervolcano-effects.html |title=Toba Supervolcano Not to Blame for Humanity's Near-Extinction |website=Livescience.com |date=2013-04-29 |accessdate=2017-01-08}}</ref> The Toba event is the most closely studied supereruption.<ref> *{{Harvnb|Chesner|others|1991}}, p. 200; {{Harvnb|Jones|2007}}, p. 174; {{Harvnb|Oppenheimer|2002}}, pp. 1593–1594; {{Harvnb|Ninkovich|others|1978}} *{{cite web |url=http://toba.arch.ox.ac.uk/index.htm |title=The Toba Supervolcano And Human Evolution |publisher=Toba.arch.ox.ac.uk |accessdate=2013-08-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121212021704/http://toba.arch.ox.ac.uk/index.htm |archivedate=2012-12-12 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.geo.mtu.edu/~raman/VBigIdeas/Supereruptions_files/Super-eruptionsGeolSocLon.pdf |format=PDF |title=The Geological Society : Super-eruptions |publisher=Geo.mtu.edu |accessdate=2015-03-28}}</ref>
==Supereruption== {{See also|List of large volcanic eruptions}} The Toba eruption or Toba event occurred at the present location of [[Lake Toba]] in [[Indonesia]], about {{val|75,000|900|u=years}} [[Before Present]] (BP) according to [[potassium argon dating]].<ref> *{{Harvnb|Ninkovich|others|1978}}. *{{Harvnb|Chesner|others|1991}}.</ref> This eruption was the last and largest of four eruptions of Toba during the [[Quaternary]] period, and is also recognized from its diagnostic horizon of ashfall, the youngest Toba [[tuff]] (YTT).<ref> *{{Harvnb|Chesner|others|1991}}, p. 200; {{Harvnb|Jones|2007}}, p. 174; {{Harvnb|Oppenheimer|2002}}, pp. 1593–1594; {{Harvnb|Ninkovich|others|1978}} *{{Harvnb|Rose|Chesner|1987}}, p. 913; {{Harvnb|Zielinski|others|1996}}.</ref> It had an estimated [[volcanic explosivity index]] of 8 (the highest rating of any known eruption on Earth); it made a sizable contribution to the 100×30 km [[caldera]] complex.<ref>{{Harvnb|Oppenheimer|2002}}, p. 1593.</ref> [[Dense-rock equivalent]] (DRE) estimates of eruptive volume for the eruption vary between {{val|2000|u=km³}} and {{val|3000|u=km³}} – the most common DRE estimate is {{val|2800|u=km³}} (about {{val|7|e=15|u=kg}}) of erupted magma, of which {{val|800|u=km³}} was deposited as ash fall.<ref>{{Harvnb|Jones|2007}}, p. 174; {{Harvnb|Rose|Chesner|1987}}, p. 913.</ref>
The erupted mass was 100 times greater than that of the largest volcanic eruption in recent history, the 1815 eruption of [[Mount Tambora]] in Indonesia, which caused the 1816 "[[Year Without a Summer]]" in the Northern Hemisphere.<ref>{{Harvnb|Petraglia|others|2007}}, p. 114; {{Harvnb|Zielinski|others|1996}}, p. 837.</ref> Toba's erupted mass deposited an ash layer about {{convert|15|cm|in}} thick over the whole of [[South Asia]]. A blanket of volcanic ash was also deposited over the [[Indian Ocean]], and the [[Arabian Sea]], and [[South China Sea]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Jones|2007}}, p. 173</ref> Deep-sea cores retrieved from the South China Sea have extended the known reach of the eruption, suggesting that the {{val|2800|u=km³}} calculation of the erupted mass is a minimum value or even an underestimate.<ref>{{Harvnb|Jones|2007}}, p. 174; {{Harvnb|Oppenheimer|2002}}. pp. 1593–1596.</ref>
==Volcanic winter and cooling computer models == Biologist Michael R. Rampino and volcanologist Stephen Self argue that the eruption caused a "brief, dramatic cooling or 'volcanic winter'", which resulted in a drop of the global mean surface temperature by 3–5 °C.<ref>{{Harvnb|Rampino|Self|1993a}}, ''passim''.</ref> Evidence from [[Greenland]] [[ice core]]s indicates a 1,000-year period of low [[δ18O|''δ''<sup>18</sup>O]] and increased dust deposition immediately following the eruption. The eruption may have caused this 1,000-year period of cooler temperatures (stadial), two centuries of which could be accounted for by the persistence of the Toba stratospheric loading.<ref>{{Harvnb|Zielinski|others|1996}}, pp. 837–840.</ref> Rampino and Self believe that global cooling was already underway at the time of the eruption, but that the process was slow; YTT "may have provided the extra 'kick' that caused the climate system to switch from warm to cold states".<ref>{{Harvnb|Rampino|Self|1992}}, p. 52; {{Harvnb|Rampino|Self|1993a}}, p. 277.</ref> Although Clive Oppenheimer rejects the hypothesis that the eruption triggered the last glaciation,<ref>{{Harvnb|Robock|others|2009}} seem to agree on that.</ref> he agrees that it may have been responsible for a millennium of cool climate prior to the 19th [[Dansgaard-Oeschger event]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Oppenheimer|2002}}, p. 1606.</ref>
According to Alan Robock, who has also published [[nuclear winter]] papers, the Toba eruption did not precipitate the last glacial period. However, assuming an emission of six billion tons of [[sulphur dioxide]], his computer simulations concluded that a maximum global cooling of approximately 15 °C occurred for three years after the eruption, and that this cooling would last for decades, devastating life.<ref><!-- name=robock2009 -->{{Harvnb|Robock|others|2009}}.</ref> Because the saturated [[adiabatic lapse rate]] is 4.9 °C/1,000 m for temperatures above freezing,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://goldbook.iupac.org/A00144.html |title=IUPAC Gold Book - adiabatic lapse rate in atmospheric chemistry |publisher=Goldbook.iupac.org |date=2014-02-24 |accessdate=2015-03-28}}</ref> the [[tree line]] and the [[snow line]] were around 3,000 m (9,900 ft) lower at this time. The climate recovered over a few decades, and Robock found no evidence that the 1,000-year cold period seen in Greenland ice core records had resulted from the Toba eruption. In contrast, Oppenheimer believes that estimates of a drop in surface temperature by 3–5 °C are probably too high, and he suggests that temperatures dropped only by 1 °C.<ref>{{Harvnb|Oppenheimer|2002}}, pp. 1593, 1601.</ref> Robock has criticized Oppenheimer's analysis, arguing that it is based on simplistic [[Standard score|T-forcing]] relationships.<ref><!-- name=robock2009 -->{{Harvnb|Robock|others|2009}}.</ref>
Despite these different estimates, scientists agree that a supereruption of the scale at Toba must have led to very extensive ash-fall layers and injection of noxious gases into the atmosphere, with worldwide effects on weather and climate.<ref>{{Harvnb|Self|Blake|2008}}, p. 41.</ref> In addition, the Greenland ice core data display an abrupt [[climate change]] around this time,<ref>{{Harvnb|Zielinski|others|1996}}, p. 837.</ref> but there is no consensus that the eruption directly generated the 1,000-year cold period seen in Greenland or triggered the last glaciation.<ref>{{Harvnb|Robock|others|2009}} (page?).</ref>
=== Physical data contradicting the winter hypothesis === Archaeologists, led by the University of Cambridge's Dr Christine Lane, in 2013, reported finding a microscopic layer of glassy volcanic ash in sediments of [[Lake Malawi]], and definitively linked the ash to the 75,000-year-old Toba super-eruption, but found no change in fossil type close to the ash layer, something that would be expected following a severe [[volcanic winter]]. They concluded that the largest known volcanic eruption in the history of the human species did not significantly alter the climate of East Africa,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://phys.org/news/2013-05-volcanic-winter-toba-super-eruption.html |title=Doubt over 'volcanic winter' after Toba super-eruption. 2013 |publisher=Phys.org |date=2013-05-02 |accessdate=2013-08-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/110/20/8025.full.pdf |title=Ash from the Toba supereruption in Lake Malawi shows no volcanic winter in East Africa at 75 ka |format=PDF |accessdate=2015-03-28 |doi=10.1073/pnas.1301474110 |volume=110 |issue=20 |date=2013 |journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences |pages=8025–8029 |pmid=23630269 |pmc=3657767 |last1=Lane |first1=CS |last2=Chorn |first2=BT |last3=Johnson |first3=TC|bibcode=2013PNAS..110.8025L }}</ref> attracting criticism from Richard Roberts.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.pnas.org/content/110/33/E3047.full |last1=Roberts |first1=RG |last2=Storey |first2=M |last3=Haslamc |first3=M |title=Toba supereruption: Age and impact on East African ecosystems |doi=10.1073/pnas.1308550110 |volume=110 |issue=33 |date=2013 |journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences |page=E3047|pmc=3746893 |bibcode=2013PNAS..110E3047R }}</ref> Lane explained, "We examined smear slides at a 2-mm interval, corresponding to subdecadal resolution, and X-ray fluorescence scans run at 200-µm intervals correspond to subannual resolution. We observed no obvious change in sediment composition or Fe/Ti ratio, suggesting that no thermally driven overturn of the water column occurred following the Toba supereruption."<ref>{{Cite journal |url=http://www.pnas.org/content/110/33/E3048.full |title=Reply to Roberts et al.: A subdecadal record of paleoclimate around the Youngest Toba Tuff in Lake Malawi |last=Lane |first=CS |journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences |doi=10.1073/pnas.1309815110 |pmid= |access-date= |volume=110 |issue=33 |date=2013 |pages=E3048|pmc=3746898 |bibcode=2013PNAS..110E3048L }}</ref> In 2015, a new study on the climate of East Africa supported Lane's conclusion, that there was "no significant cooling associated with Mount Toba".<ref>{{Cite journal |url= |title=High-resolution paleoecological records from Lake Malawi show no significant cooling associated with the Mount Toba supereruption at ca. 75 ka |last=Jackson |first=LJ |last2=Stone |first2=JR |last3=Cohen |first3=AS |last4=Yost |first4=CL |date=2015 |journal=Geology |doi=10.1130/G36917.1 |pmid= |access-date= |volume=43 |issue=9 |pages=823–826|bibcode=2015Geo....43..823J }}</ref>
==Genetic bottleneck theory== The Toba eruption has been linked to a [[genetic bottleneck]] in human evolution about 70,000 years ago,<ref>{{Harvnb|Gibbons|1993|p=27}}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Rampino|Self|1993a}}</ref> which may have resulted from a severe reduction in the size of the total human population due to the effects of the eruption on the global climate.<ref>{{Harvnb|Ambrose|1998}}, ''passim''; {{Harvnb|Gibbons|1993}}, p. 27; {{Harvnb|McGuire|2007}}, pp. 127–128; {{Harvnb|Rampino|Ambrose|2000}}, pp. 78–80; {{Harvnb|Rampino|Self|1993b}}, pp. 1955.</ref> According to the genetic bottleneck theory, between 50,000 and 100,000 years ago, human populations sharply decreased to 3,000–10,000 surviving individuals.<ref>{{Harvnb|Ambrose|1998}}; {{Harvnb|Rampino|Ambrose|2000}}, pp. 71, 80.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/science/horizon/1999/supervolcanoes_script.shtml |title=Science & Nature - Horizon - Supervolcanoes |publisher=BBC.co.uk |accessdate=2015-03-28}}</ref> It is supported by some genetic evidence suggesting that today's humans are descended from a very small population of between 1,000 and 10,000 breeding pairs that existed about 70,000 years ago.<ref><!-- name=a1998 -->{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/2975862.stm|title=When humans faced extinction|publisher=BBC|date=2003-06-09|accessdate=2007-01-05}}</ref>{{Scientific citation needed|date=August 2018}}
Proponents of the genetic bottleneck theory (including Robock) suggest that the Toba eruption resulted in a global ecological disaster, including destruction of vegetation along with severe drought in the [[tropical rainforest]] belt and in monsoonal regions. For example, a 10-year volcanic winter triggered by the eruption could have largely destroyed the food sources of humans and caused a severe reduction in population sizes.<ref><!-- name=robock2009 -->{{Harvnb|Robock|others|2009}}.</ref> Τhese environmental changes may have generated population bottlenecks in many species, including [[hominid]]s;<ref>{{Harvnb|Rampino|Ambrose|2000}}, p. 80.</ref> this in turn may have accelerated differentiation from within the smaller human population. Therefore, the genetic differences among modern humans may reflect changes within the last 70,000 years, rather than gradual differentiation over hundreds of thousands of years.<ref><!-- name=a1998 -->{{Harvnb|Ambrose|1998}}, pp. 623–651.</ref>
Other research has cast doubt on a link between Toba and a genetic bottleneck. For example, ancient [[stone tool]]s in southern India were found above and below a thick layer of ash from the Toba eruption and were very similar across these layers, suggesting that the dust clouds from the eruption did not wipe out this local population.<ref>{{cite news |title=Mount Toba Eruption – Ancient Humans Unscathed, Study Claims |date=6 July 2007 |url=http://anthropology.net/2007/07/06/mount-toba-eruption-ancient-humans-unscathed-study-claims/ |website=Anthropology.net |accessdate=2008-04-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |title=Super-eruption: no problem? |journal=Nature |date=July 2007 |first=Katherine |last=Sanderson |volume= |issue= |pages= |doi=10.1038/news070702-15 |url=http://www.nature.com/news/2007/070702/full/news070702-15.html |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081207012423/http://www.nature.com/news/2007/070702/full/news070702-15.html |archivedate=December 7, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |website=john hawks weblog |date=5 July 2007 |url=http://johnhawks.net/weblog/reviews/archaeology/middle/petraglia_toba_india_continuity_2007.html |title= At last, the death of the Toba bottleneck |author=John Hawks |authorlink=John D. Hawks}}</ref> Additional archaeological evidence from southern and northern India also suggests a lack of evidence for effects of the eruption on local populations, leading the authors of the study to conclude, "many forms of life survived the supereruption, contrary to other research which has suggested significant animal extinctions and genetic bottlenecks".<ref>See also {{cite web |url=http://anthropology.net/2010/02/25/newly-discovered-archaeological-sites-in-india-reveals-ancient-life-before-toba/ |title=Newly Discovered Archaeological Sites in India Reveals Ancient Life before Toba |date=25 February 2010 |website=Anthropology.net |accessdate=28 February 2010}}</ref> However, evidence from pollen analysis has suggested prolonged deforestation in South Asia, and some researchers have suggested that the Toba eruption may have forced humans to adopt new adaptive strategies, which may have permitted them to replace [[Neanderthal]]s and "other archaic human species".<ref>{{cite news |title=Supervolcano Eruption In Sumatra Deforested India 73,000 Years ago |newspaper=ScienceDaily |date=24 November 2009 |url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2009/11/091123142739.htm}}</ref><ref><!-- name=williams2009 -->{{Harvnb|Williams|others|2009}}.</ref>
Additional caveats include difficulties in estimating the global and regional climatic impacts of the eruption and lack of conclusive evidence for the eruption preceding the bottleneck.<ref>{{Harvnb|Oppenheimer|2002}}, pp. 1605, 1606.</ref> Furthermore, genetic analysis of [[Alu sequence]]s across the entire [[human genome]] has shown that the effective human population size was less than 26,000 at 1.2 million years ago; possible explanations for the low population size of human ancestors may include repeated population bottlenecks or periodic replacement events from competing ''[[Homo]]'' subspecies.<ref>If these results are accurate, then, even before the emergence of ''Homo sapiens'' in Africa, ''Homo erectus'' population was unusually small when the species was spreading around the world. See {{Harvnb|Huff|others|2010}}, p.6; {{Harvnb|Gibbons|2010}}.</ref>
===Genetic bottlenecks in other mammals=== Some evidence points to genetic bottlenecks in other animals in the wake of the Toba eruption. The populations of the Eastern African [[chimpanzee]],<ref>{{Harvnb|Goldberg|1996}}</ref> Bornean [[orangutan]],<ref>{{Harvnb|Steiper|2006}}</ref> central Indian [[Rhesus macaque|macaque]],<ref>{{Harvnb|Hernandez|others|2007}}</ref> [[cheetah]], and [[tiger]],<ref>{{Harvnb|Luo|others|2004}}</ref> all recovered from very low numbers around 70,000–55,000 years ago.
The separation of the nuclear gene pools of eastern and western lowland [[gorilla]]s has been estimated to have occurred about 77,700 years ago.<ref>{{Harvnb|Thalman|others|2007}}</ref>
==Migration after Toba== The exact geographic distribution of human populations at the time of the eruption is not known, and surviving populations may have lived in [[Africa]] and subsequently migrated to other parts of the world. Analyses of [[mitochondrial DNA]] have estimated that the [[Recent African origin of modern humans#Exodus from Africa|major migration from Africa]] occurred 60,000–70,000 years ago,<ref>{{cite web|title=New 'Molecular Clock' Aids Dating Of Human Migration History |url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2009/06/090604124023.htm |work=[[ScienceDaily]] |date=22 June 2009 |accessdate=2009-06-30}}</ref> consistent with dating of the Toba eruption to around 75,000 years ago.
==Criticism== A study by Chad Yost and colleagues of cores from [[Lake Malawi]] dating to the period of the Toba supereruption showed no evidence of a volcanic winter, and they argue that there was no effect on African humans.<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0047248417302750|title=Subdecadal phytolith and charcoal records from Lake Malawi, East Africa imply minimal effects on human evolution from the ∼74 ka Toba supereruption|author1=Yost, Chad|display-authors=etal|journal=Journal of Human Evolution|date=March 2018|volume=116|publisher=Elsevier}}</ref> In the view of [[John D. Hawks|John Hawks]], the study confirms evidence from a variety of studies that the eruption did not have a major climatic effect or any effect on human numbers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://johnhawks.net/weblog/reviews/climate/toba-bottleneck-didnt-happen-2018.html|title=The so-called Toba bottleneck didn't happen|date=9 February 2018|first=John |last=Hawks|website=john hawks weblog}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Volcanoes|Evolutionary biology}} * [[Early human migrations]] * [[Most recent common ancestor]] * [[Quaternary extinction event]] * [[Recent African origin of modern humans]] * [[Timeline of volcanism on Earth]] * [[Wallace Line]]
==Citations and notes== {{Reflist|30em}}
==References== {{bots|deny=Citation bot}} {{refbegin|colwidth=30em}} *{{Cite journal |last1= Ambrose |first1= Stanley H. |title= Late Pleistocene human population bottlenecks, volcanic winter, and differentiation of modern humans |journal= [[Journal of Human Evolution]] |year= 1998 |volume= 34 |issue= 6 |pages= 623–651 |doi= 10.1006/jhev.1998.0219 | pmid= 9650103 |url= http://www.bradshawfoundation.com/stanley_ambrose.php |ref=harv}} *{{Cite journal |ref=CITEREFChesnerothers1991 |first1=C.A. |last1=Chesner |first2=J.A. |last2=Westgate |first3=W.I. |last3=Rose |first4=R. |last4=Drake |first5=A. |last5=Deino |title=Eruptive History of Earth's Largest Quaternary caldera (Toba, Indonesia) Clarified |journal=Geology |volume=19 |pages=200–203 |date=March 1991 |doi=10.1130/0091-7613(1991)019<0200:EHOESL>2.3.CO;2 |url=http://www.geo.mtu.edu/~raman/papers/ChesnerGeology.pdf|bibcode = 1991Geo....19..200C}} *{{Cite journal|ref= CITEREFGibbons1993|first1= Ann |last1= Gibbons|date= 1 October 1993|title= Pleistocene Population Explosions|journal= Science|volume= 262 |issue= 5130 |pages= 27–28|doi= 10.1126/science.262.5130.27 |pmid= 17742951 |url= http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/pdf_extract/262/5130/27|bibcode = 1993Sci...262...27G }} *{{cite news|ref=CITEREFGibbons2010 |first1=Ann |last1=Gibbons |title=Human Ancestors Were an Endangered Species
